questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to his back. An urgent CT scan reveals an aortic dissection. As the medical team plans for urgent intervention, they discuss the structures passing through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to understand the potential complications and management of the patient's condition. The structure that passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm is?
questions.solution:
The Hemi-azygous vein passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

The aortic opening of the diaphragm, also known as the aortic hiatus, is a passage in the diaphragm through which structures such as the aorta, thoracic duct, and azygos vein pass.

The hemi-azygous vein is a venous structure that typically drains into the azygos vein, which, in turn, drains into the superior vena cava. It courses through the aortic opening of the diaphragm, making it the structure of interest in this question.

Other Options:

Left vagus nerve: While the vagus nerve does traverse the diaphragm, it usually passes through the oesophagal hiatus rather than the aortic opening.

Right phrenic nerve: The right phrenic nerve supplies motor innervation to the diaphragm and typically courses through the diaphragm separately from the aortic opening.

Right vagus nerve: Similar to the left vagus nerve, the right vagus nerve usually passes through the oesophagal hiatus rather than the aortic opening.

questions.text: Which of the following about lepromin test is not true?

choices.text: It is negative in most children in the first 4 months
It is an important aid to classify type of leprosy disease
BCG vacination may convert lepra reaction from negative to positive

questions.solution:
Lepromin test is not a diagnostic test. It has 2 major drawbacks.

  • Positive results in non-cases
  • Negative results in lepromatous and near-lepromatous cases

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child is brought with a history of impaired vision and severe photophobia. On examination, he has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue eyes. Which of the following are not derived from the precursor amino acid, whose metabolism is impaired in this child?

DOPA- dihydroxyphenylalanine, GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with impaired vision, light hair, light skin colour, and pale blue iris is suggestive of albinism, which is a disorder of tyrosine metabolism where there is a defect in melanin synthesis. Glutamate is the precursor amino acid of GABA (γ-aminobutyric acid), not tyrosine.

Tyrosine is a precursor of melanin, thyroxin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

  • Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxy phenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a monooxygenase that contains copper.
  • Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.
  • Formation of catecholamines: Epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are produced by the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia.
  • Formation of thyroid hormones: Tyrosine residues are iodinated to form 3-mono-iodo-tyrosine (MIT) and 3,5-di-iodo-tyrosine (DIT). These are coupled to give rise to triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine (thyroxine or T4).

The series of reactions involving the production of catecholamines is shown in the image below.

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.
 
There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterized by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in peristalsis by causing relaxation?
questions.solution:
The release of NO and VIP (Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) from the cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction relaxes the segment of the intestine ahead of the stimulus.

Peristalsis involves the contraction of a segment of intestine behind the bolus of food and relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus of food.

Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of intestine.

Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which causes relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of a bolus of food.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, cough, and fatigue. Suspecting a viral aetiology, the physician orders laboratory tests to confirm the diagnosis. Among the tests requested is the detection of viral RNA to identify the specific virus causing the patient's symptoms. Which of the following methods can be used for the detection of RNA?
questions.solution:
The method that can be used for the detection of RNA is northern blotting. Here, the mixture of mRNA molecules is separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with radiolabeled probes.

PCR (polymerase chain reaction) is a technique used to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It can be used to synthesize millions of copies of the selected DNA sequence in a few hours, enabling the detection of even trace amounts of DNA in a sample. Therefore, PCR is used for:

  • Detecting mutant DNA 
  • DNA fingerprinting for forensic analysis- Detection of DNA from small amounts of samples from the crime scene
  • Detection of latent viral infections
  • Carrier detection of cystic fibrosis

Real-time PCR is used for quantitation of the number of viruses present in a sample e.g. viral load in HIV or HBV, so that the treatment modalities can be planned and the response to treatment can be assessed.

RT-PCR or reverse transcriptase PCR is also used for the detection of RNA. It can be used to quantify mRNA levels by generating complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme. 

Western blot, also called immunoblots, is a technique used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented to OPD with complaints of fever left eye lid swelling for the past two days. He had a mild flu-like illness a week ago but no history of trauma. There is no chemosis or any protrusion of the eyeball. Visual acuity, IOP, ocular motility, and pupils all were normal. Slit-lamp examination was unremarkable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with eyelid swelling and fever following an infection without proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia with normal visual acuity are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis.

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum. The commonly implicated bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes.

The mode of spread of infection can occur through skin trauma, insect bites, acute hordeolum, dacryocystitis, conjunctivitis, sinusitis, Upper respiratory tract infection, and middle ear infection.

Clinical features include,

  • Tender, firm, erythematous eyelid swelling
  • Conjunctiva - usually no chemosis
  • Proptosis - absent
  • Ocular movements - normal
  • Visual acuity - normal
  • Systemic symptoms: fever, leucocytosis

Treatment: 

  • Antibiotics - oral or i.v depending on severity.
  • Systemic analgesics
  • Warm compresses

Complications include spread of infection and may develop into orbital cellulitis, abscess formation, meningitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option A:  Endophthalmitis is the inflammation of the inner coats of the eye due to intraocular colonization of infectious agents. There is exudation within intraocular fluids. It generally occurs after trauma, surgery, or due to an endogenous source. It is characterized by poor visual acuity, corneal edema, hypopyon, vitreous inflammation, and poor fundus visualization. 

Option B: Orbital cellulitis refers to the acute infection of the contents of the orbit behind the orbital septum. Features include:

  • Pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis.
  • Increased pain with movement of eyes and ophthalmoplegia (decreased ocular motility) is a classic symptom
  • A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve, diplopia.
  • Systemic symptoms include malaise and fever.
The image shown below is of a patient with orbital cellulitis and orbital apex syndrome presenting with complete ptosis, proptosis, total ophthalmoplegia, chemosis, and congestion.

Option D- Lid tumors can be variable in etiology. A few examples include squamous papilloma (raspberry-like growth), eyelid actinic keratosis (yellow plaque-like lesions), or capillary hemangiomas (bright red colored lesions over the eyelids).

questions.text: A patient presented with foreign body sensation, redness, and excessive watering from the right eye for 15 days after a twig brushed against his eye. On examination, an irregularly shaped ulcer with a whitish feathery appearance, and satellite lesions were seen in his right eye. Which among the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a fungal ulcer and the most appropriate treatment is amphotericin B drops.

Fungal or mycotic keratitis is commonly caused by Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida albicans. They are characteristically seen after injury with vegetative matter like thorns or wooden sticks.

Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but are usually milder in comparison to a bacterial ulcer. The clinical signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes
  • Dry slough with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs
    • Natamycin, voriconazole, and amphotericin B drops are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium.
    • Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic antifungal agents such as oral ketoconazole or voriconazole are considered if the ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated or in suspected endophthalmitis
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Removal of necrotic material by scraping with a spatula
    • Cauterization with pure carbolic acid or trichloracetic acid
    • Therapeutic keratoplasty 

The image below shows a fungal corneal ulcer with a hypopyon.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

Features of Plasmodium falciparum on peripheral smear are Maurer’s dots, ring form, accole form, and banana-shaped gametocytes.

questions.text: During a rotation in the acute medical ward, you observe a patient in cardiogenic shock being started on a low-dose dopamine infusion. Which of the following would you expect to increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
At lower doses (< 2 μg/kg), dopamine only stimulates dopamine receptors in renal vasculature, causing increased urine output.

As the dose increases (2-5 μg/kg), additional cardiac stimulant action (β1) is also seen.

At very high doses (5-15 μg/kg), vasoconstriction (α1) is additionally seen.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presenting with features of meningitis was further evaluated. CSF analysis shows normal glucose level, increased protein level, increased lymphocyte count, and increased opening pressure. Which of the following stains would help identify the organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the CSF findings and the given clinical scenario of an HIV-positive patient with features of meningitis, aetiology is likely to be of fungal origin. The organism is likely to be cryptococcus and the stain used for identifying it is an India ink stain.

Cryptococcal meningitis is the most common cause of meningitis in an immunocompromised HIV patient. It presents with subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. The CSF profile shows elevations in WBC with lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein levels, and reduced to normal levels of glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated.

Indian ink is a negative staining method that provides a uniformly coloured background. The unstained organisms stand out in contrast to the background. It is useful in the demonstration of organisms with capsules that do not take simple stains. It is also used to stain slender bacteria like spirochetes. The India ink preparation is widely employed to detect the presence of Cryptococcus neoformans. It is seen as a globular, encapsulated yeast cell with or without budding, between 5 to 20 μm in diameter in size. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is seen against a black background.

Cryptococcus can be cultured from biologic samples like the CSF, sputum, and skin biopsy on routine fungal and bacterial culture media. Colonies are opaque, white-to-cream coloured, and may turn orange-tan or brown after prolonged incubation. They have a mucoid appearance due to the presence of the capsule around the yeast cells.

The image below shows the fungus Cryptococcus, stained with Indian ink.

Initiation with amphotericin B with flucytosine, which is followed by oral fluconazole as a maintenance treatment is the standard of care.

Other options.

Option A: Gram stain can identify Streptococcus pneumoniae or Neisseria meningitidis, which has elevated neutrophils, decreased glucose level, and increased protein level.

Option B: Gomori methenamine silver stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii which causes fungal pneumonia.

Option C: Acid-fast stain is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis which has lymphocyte predominance, decreased glucose, and elevated proteins.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For Cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A biochemist wanted to study the differences between a cancer cell and a normal cell. Cancer cells derive energy mainly from __________.
questions.solution:
Cancer cells derive energy mainly from glycolysis.

Metabolic reprogramming in cancer cells: 

  • Cancer cells utilize large amounts of glucose and metabolize it to lactic acid, even in the presence of oxygen. This effect was termed as the Warburg effect.
  • The increased rate of glycolysis is due to certain defects in the mitochondrial electron transport chain. Besides, this enhanced glycolysis enables the cancer cells to proliferate in the reduced oxygen tension conditions, which is seen in tumors. This switch from aerobic to anaerobic glucose metabolism also acts as an impetus to tumorigenesis.
  • The increased glucose consumption is used as a carbon source for anabolic processes needed to support cell proliferation such as the de novo generation of nucleotides, lipids, and proteins.
  • Also, the major isoenzyme of pyruvate kinase in cancer cells is PK-2 (in contrast to PK-1 in normal cells), which appears to play a role in Warburg effect.

Note:

This effect is the basis for detecting cancers by FDG-PET scanning.

questions.text: A young woman presented with abdominal distention and a palpable pelvic mass and was evaluated. Based on the histopathological image given below, which of the following tumours is suspected?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows Schiller Duval's body. It is seen in the endodermal sinus tumour (yolk sac tumour).

A yolk sac tumour/endodermal sinus tumour is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumour of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. It is usually unilateral and highly malignant. It is most often seen in children and young women. It usually presents as abdominal distention and a palpable pelvic mass. 

Grossly, the yolk-sac tumour appears yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), and forms a solid mass.

On histology, most of the yolk sac tumours have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumour cells within a space that is also lined by tumour cells.

These tumours are usually associated with raised AFP and alpha-1 antitrypsin. Therefore, serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein can serve as a reliable tumour marker in post-treatment surveillance.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumours.

Other options:

Option A: Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland-like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

The image given below shows Call-Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumours.

Option B: Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumours composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. The tumour cells grow in cords or sheets that are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. They are usually infiltrated by lymphocytes.

Option D: Krukenberg tumour is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasizes to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Kruckenberg tumour.

questions.text: Which among the following is an example of epimers?
questions.solution:
D-Glucose and D-mannose are examples of epimers.

Isomers that differ in configuration around only one specific carbon atom (with the exception of the carbonyl carbon) are defined as epimers of each other.

Examples for epimers of glucose:

  • Mannose (epimerized at carbon 2)
  • Galactose (epimerized at carbon 4)

questions.text: Glucose transporter in the myocytes, under the influence of insulin, is ________
questions.solution:
Glucose transporter in the myocytes, under the influence of insulin, is GLUT 4.

Glucose transport in our body mainly occurs through sodium-independent glucose transporters, which include GLUT transporters, and to a small extent through sodium-dependent glucose transporters, which include SGLT-1 and SGLT-2. Insulin induces the movement of intracellular GLUT 4 molecules to the cell surface and thus increases glucose uptake.

questions.text: How long does a male worker undergoing sterilization  get enhanced sickness benefit at full wages under the ESI act ?
questions.solution:
Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration of up to 7 days in case of vasectomy and up to 14 days in case of tubectomy.

Few important points to be known about the ESI Act:

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill.
  • The employee contributes 0.75% of wages.
  • State and Central governments share medical expenditure in the ratio of 1:7.
  • Medical benefit: Full medical care
  • Sickness benefits: 70% of the average daily wages and is payable for 91 days.
  • Extended sickness benefit: Payable for up to 2 years for a set of 34 diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, Myasthenia Gravis, Glaucoma, Coronary artery disease etc.
  • Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration of up to 7 days in case of vasectomy and up to 14 days in case of tubectomy.
  • Maternity benefit: Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy.
  • Funeral expenses: Cash not exceeding Rs.15,000.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding

  • Defense 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage 
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- no cash benefit, full medical care is provided.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of daily wage for a duration of 91 days in one year 
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years for 34 specified diseases 
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
  • Maternity Benefit – Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy
  • Dependance Benefit– is at 90% daily wages, lifelong for the spouse and parents and till the age of 18 years for any dependant's child, however, the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter is married earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits – temporary disability – is as long as the person is disabled at 90% daily wages. Permanent disability – the lifetime pension 
  • Funeral Benefit – Rs.15,000/-
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs. 10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from workman compensation act 
  • Exemption from maternity benefit act 
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition (Page no: 877)

https://www.esic.nic.in/information-benefits.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding a 'Reference Indian adult man'?

questions.text: The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition?
questions.solution:
In the provided Darrow-Yannet diagram, hypoosmotic volume expansion indicates SIADH. In SIADH, there is an excessive release of ADH, leading to increased water retention in the body. As a result, ECF volume increases, while ECF osmolality decreases. Fluid from the ECF moves into the ICF until osmotic equilibrium is restored, causing an increase in ICF volume and a decrease in ICF osmolality. The diagramatic representation is mentioned below.

The Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions are shown above

Other options :

Option b:  Diarrhea is associated with iso-osmotic volume contraction. Due to loss of fluids, only plasma volume decreases without decrease in osmolarity. 

Option c: In Central diabetes insipidus, is associated with Hyperosmotic volume contraction. It is associated with inability to secrete Anti-diuretic Hormone(ADH) that leads to primary loss of water (decreased ECF and ICF) which leads to hypernatremia increasing the plasma osmolality and leading to dehydration.

Option d: Adrenal insufficiency is associated with hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is not involved in sulphur containing amino acid metabolism?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) is not involved in sulphur containing amino acid metabolism.

Vitamin B6, B9 and B12 are involved in sulphur containing amino acid metabolism.

  • Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is the co-enzyme of cystathionine β synthase.
  • Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) and B12 (Cobalamin) are involved in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine by methionine synthase.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is effective in the delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Aprepitant is the drug preferred for delayed onset vomiting after cancer chemotherapy.

Nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy occur in two phases:

  • The acute phase is seen within 24 hours and occurs in almost all patients receiving chemotherapy. In response to chemotherapeutic agents, the enterochromaffin cells in the small intestine secrete serotonin, which acts on the 5HT3 receptors and causes vomiting. This phase is treated by 5HT3 antagonists such as ondansetron, granisetron, and palanosetron.
     
  • The delayed phase is seen on days 2-5 and occurs only in some patients. It occurs in response to stimulation of NK-1 receptors by substance P. 5HT3 antagonists are not effective against the delayed phase, and NK-1 receptor antagonists are used in these patients. 

NK-1 receptor antagonists include aprepitant and its parenteral formulation, fosaprepitant, rolapitant, and netupitant. These drugs are usually administered in combination with 5HT3 antagonists and dexamethasone for highly emetogenic chemotherapy. A fixed-dose combination of netupitant and palanosetron has been approved to cover both the acute and delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A patient on chemotherapy read an article about bone marrow suppression caused due to chemotherapeutic drugs. Which of the following drugs causes bone marrow suppression?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow suppression is seen with vinblastine.

Vinblastine and vinorelbine have prominent bone marrow depression.

Bone marrow-sparing cytotoxic drugs are:

  • Vincristine
  • Bleomycin
  • L-asparaginase

questions.text: A surgeon performing a difficult neck dissection has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve. Which of the following triangles of the neck, is he probably dissecting?
questions.solution:
The surgeon has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve, which has its major course in the carotid triangle.

The hypoglossal nerve leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It then descends to the carotid triangle. Here, in the carotid triangle, the nerve makes a loop lateral to the internal and external carotid arteries. The nerve then ascends to the digastric triangle, and reaches further up supplying the muscles of the tongue.

Contents of the carotid triangle include:

  • Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
  • Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Spinal part of the accessory
  • Sympathetic chain
  • Ansa cervicalis

questions.text: Mallory body or alcoholic hyaline body is an eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion in liver cells which is characteristic of alcoholic liver disease. What is the intermediate filament that is present predominantly in these inclusions?
questions.solution:
Mallory bodies, also called alcoholic hyaline  bodies are predominantly composed of keratin intermediate filaments (keratin 8 and 18).

These are clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion bodies in ballooned liver cells that are seen in alcoholic liver disease. 

Cytoskeletal proteins: 

  • They are divided into five classes: 
    • Keratin filaments (characteristic of epithelial cells)
    • Neurofilaments (neurons)
    • Desmin filaments (muscle cells)
    • Vimentin filaments (connective tissue cells)
    • Glial filaments (astrocytes)
  • The neurofibrillary tangle found in the brain in Alzheimer's disease contains neurofilaments and other proteins.

The image given shows the Mallory bodies marked in arrows.

Related Pearl: Mallory Bodies vs. Councilman Bodies

Mallory bodies Councilman bodies
Intra-cytoplasmic inclusions  Acidophilic apoptotic bodies
Due to aggregation of cytoskeletal intermediate filament  Due to hepatocyte apoptosis  

Appears as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes.

 Entire hepatocyte shrinks and appears as intense eosinophilic stained bodies

Seen in

  • Alcoholic hepatitis
  • Primary biliary cholangitis 
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma 

Seen in  

  • Acute viral hepatitis
  • Yellow fever

Mallory bodies seen as clumped, amorphous eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes

Councilman bodies where the entire cell is shrunken into intense eosinophilic apoptotic body

questions.text: Pharmacovigilance means _______.

choices.text: Monitoring of unethical trade of drugs

questions.solution:
Pharmacovigilance deals with monitoring of drug safety.

WHO definition of pharmacovigilance: “Science and activities related to the detection, assessment, understanding, and prevention of adverse effects or any other drug-related problems”.

questions.text: “Pie in the floor” field defects are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The term "pie in the floor" defects refers to inferior quadrantic hemianopia. They are produced when the superior fibers of the optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop) are involved.

"Pie in the sky" defects

  • Refer to superior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of the inferior fibers of optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer’s loop)

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Rickettsial pox is caused by _______
questions.solution:
Rickettsial pox

  • It is caused by akari.
  • Mites are found in mice(Mus musculus)
  • Transovarial transmission occurs in mites
  • Mouse is the true reservoir

questions.text: The oral thrombin inhibitor which can be used for prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation is?
questions.solution:
The oral thrombin inhibitor which can be used for the prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation is dabigatran. However, it is contraindicated in patients with mechanical heart valves.

Ximelagatran is also an oral thrombin inhibitor, but it has been discontinued due to the risk of hepatotoxicity (Option B).

Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor used mainly in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (Option C).

Saxagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus (Option D).

questions.text: Gustafson’s method of determining age from tooth is used in which age group?
questions.solution:
Gustafson’s method is mainly useful in estimating the age of individuals above 25 years.

Gustafson’s method of estimating of age of an individual is based on physiological changes in teeth.

It is mainly useful in adults over 25 years of age.

Criteria:

Attrition: Wear and tear changes of the occlusal surface.

Periodontosis: Regression of gums surrounding the tooth resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling.

Secondary dentin: Deposition of dentin in pulp cavity.

Cementum apposition: Deposition of Cementum in the root forming incremental lines.

Root resorption: Involves both Cementum and dentin.

Transparency of the root: This is the most reliable criterion. Canals in dentin get filled by minerals and they become less transparent.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Merkel cells?

choices.text: It is located in the epidermis.
It is a type of phasic receptor.
It is innervated by type C nerve fibers.
It has a large receptive field.

questions.solution:
Merkel cells are located in the epidermis.

Merkel cell is a type of slow-adapting (tonic) receptor that projects into the epidermis from the underside. They are seen in the basal layer of the epidermis. It senses sustained touch and pressure. It is innervated by Aβ type of large myelinated nerve fibres. Like Meissner corpuscles, they have a small receptive field and provide excellent tactile localization. 

Based on how fast the mechanoreceptors can adapt to the sensation, they are divided into:

  • Phasic receptors include the receptors that adapt quickly to a constant stimulus and cannot be used to transmit a continuous signal. They detect primarily the onset, offset, and change in the stimulus. For example, Pacinian corpuscles and Meissner corpuscles. 
  • Tonic receptors are the ones that adapt slowly. They can code for stimulus intensity and duration, resulting in a long series of action potentials. For example, Merkel cells, muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs. 
  • Non-adapting receptors include the nociceptors.

questions.text: A child suffered an accidental cut injury over the knee and the area appears to be inflamed. All of the following markers decrease during the inflammatory process except?
questions.solution:
Serum Amyloid A protein increases during the inflammatory process as it is a positive acute phase reactant. It binds to microbial cell walls and may act as opsonins and fix complement.

Acute-phase proteins are plasma proteins, synthesized in the liver, whose plasma concentrations may increase several hundred-fold as part of the response to inflammatory stimuli. e.g. C-reactive protein (CRP), fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A (SAA) protein.

Other options:

Albumin, transferrin and alpha-fetoprotein are negative acute-phase reactants, which are decreased in plasma concentration during the acute-phase response.

Related Pearl: Acute phase reactants and their functions

"Positive" acute-phase proteins:

Protein

Immune system function

C-reactive protein

Opsonin on microbes

Serum amyloid P component

Opsonin

Serum amyloid A

Recruitment of immune cells to inflammatory sites

Induction of enzymes that degrade extracellular matrix

Complement factors

Opsonization, lysis, and clumping of target cells; Chemotaxis

Mannan-binding lectin

Mannan-binding lectin pathway of complement activation

Fibrinogen, prothrombin, factor VIII,
von Willebrand factor

Coagulation factors, trapping invading microbes in blood clots.
Some cause chemotaxis

Plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1)

Prevents the degradation of blood clots by inhibiting plasminogen 

Alpha 2-macroglobulin

Inhibitor of coagulation by inhibiting thrombin

Inhibitor of fibrinolysis by inhibiting plasmin

Ferritin

Binding iron, inhibiting microbe iron uptake

Hepcidin

Stimulates the internalization of ferroportin, preventing release of iron bound by ferritin within intestinal enterocytes and macrophages

Ceruloplasmin

Oxidizes iron, facilitating for ferritin, inhibiting microbe iron uptake

Haptoglobin

Binds hemoglobin, inhibiting microbe iron uptake

Orosomucoid
(Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein, AGP)

Steroid carrier

Alpha 1-antitrypsin

Serpin, downregulates inflammation

Alpha 1-antichymotrypsin

Serpin, downregulates inflammation

Thrombopoietin

Thrombocytosis

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptics is an AMPA glutamate receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Perampanel is a selective non-competitive antagonist of the AMPA-type glutamate receptor. It is approved for adjunctive therapy of focal-onset seizures.

Options A and B: Levetiracetam and brivaracetam act on SV2A proteins and modulates GABA and glutamate release.

Option D: Rufinamide acts on voltage-gated sodium channels.

questions.text: The structure labeled as D in this image below, is developed from which of following?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as D in the given image is the cerebellum, which develops from metencephalon.

The metencephalon is a part of rhombencephalon. It is characterized by basal and alar plates and forms two components: 

(a) the cerebellum, a coordination center for posture and movement, and

(b) the pons, the pathway for nerve fibers between the spinal cord and the cerebral and cerebellar cortices.

Related Pearl: Divisions of the Developing Brain

  • Cerebral cortex
  • Subcortical white matter
  • Amygdala
  • Basal ganglia
  • Hippocampus

  • Cavities: Lateral ventricles

  • Thalamus
  • Hypothalamus
  • Epithalamus
  • Subthalamus
  • Optic nerve and retina
  • Cavities: 3rd ventricle

questions.text: Multiple linear incised wounds on the inner side (ulnar border) of the forearm of a homicide victim are most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Multiple linear incised wounds on the inner side (ulnar border) of the forearm of a homicide victim is suggestive of a defence wound in case of a attack by a sharp weapon (e.g. knife)

Defence wounds: Defence wounds can be sustained when a victim is trying to save himself from attacks made by fists, feet and blunt or sharp instruments.

  • In case of a blunt instrument, fist or feet: Bruises are most common along with abrasions. Bruises are common on the extensor and ulnar aspect of the forearms, wrists, back of the hand and knuckles. The classic position for them is on the forearms and hands, which are instinctively raised to protect the eyes, face and head. They may also be seen on thighs, due to an attempt to protect genitals especially in the male victims.
  • In case of a sharp instrument:
    • In case of attack by a cutting instrument, the victim may hold up the hand or forearm and hence cuts can be seen on the ulnar side of the forearm, wrist, hand and fingers.
    • If the victim tries to seize the weapon with his hands, cuts may be present on the flexures of phalanages. It can also seen on the web between the base of the thumb and index finger.
  • Firearm injury: Arms may be used to shield trunk or head from the blast. There may be an entrance and an exit wound in the upper arm with the missile then re-penetrating the trunk.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to perform a tonsillectomy?

choices.text: At the time of the measles epidemic

questions.solution:
Tonsillectomy is contraindicated in the presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, as bleeding is more likely in the presence of acute infection.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis, as bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of an epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: Two patients have been posted for a tracheostomy procedure. The operating surgeon performs tracheostomy through the level of 2nd - 3rd tracheal rings in the first patient and  4th - 5th tracheal ring in the second patient. What is the type of tracheostomy procedure conducted in these patients respectively?

choices.text: Low tracheostomy is done in both patients

questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that Mid tracheostomy and Low tracheostomy is performed by the surgeon in first and second patient respectively.

Mid tracheostomy is done through the 2nd and 3rd ring and Low tracheostomy is done below the level of isthmus i.e through the 4th and 5th tracheal ring.

High tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (Isthmus lies against II, III, and IV tracheal ring). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: A patient presented with some visual symptoms. He is undergoing the test given below. What is this test called?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test, which is used to test color vision.

The Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test:

  • It is a spectroscopic test.
  • It consists of 85 caps of different hues in four racks and the subject is asked to rearrange the colored chips in ascending order.
  • It is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired color vision defects. 
  • An error score is used to judge the color vision, i.e. greater the score poorer will be the color vision.

Note:

Farnsworth D15 hue discrimination test is similar to the above test but it utilizes only 15 hue caps.

Few other commonly employed color vision tests includes,

  • Ishihara’s plates
  • Hardy–Rand–Rittler test
  • Edridge-Green lantern test.
  • City University test
  • Holmgrens wool-matching test
  • Naegels anamoloscope

Ishihara's plates (image below):

 

Hardy–Rand–Rittler test (image below):

 

City University test (image below):

 

Holmgrens wool test (image below):

questions.text: Following prolonged spine surgery in a prone position, a patient develops Meralgia paresthetica and complaints of pain, numbness, and paresthesia along the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. What is the root value of the involved nerve?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is due to compression neuropathy or neuroma of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. The root value of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is L2 and L3.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

questions.text:
Match the following fundal findings with their associated diseases.
1. Headlight in the fog appearance a. Toxoplasmosis uveitis
2. Splashed tomato appearance b. Central retinal vein occlusion
3. Pizza pie appearance c. Cytomegalovirus retinitis
4. Candle wax dropping appearance d. Sarcoidosis
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is 1 - a, 2 - b, 3 - c, and 4 - d.

1. Headlight in the fog appearance a. Toxoplasmosis uveitis
2. Splashed tomato appearance b. Central retinal vein occlusion
3. Pizza pie appearance c. Cytomegalovirus retinitis
4. Candle wax dropping appearance d. Sarcoidosis

 

Toxoplasmosis can cause severe vitritis. This leads to an impaired fundus examination that will give a "headlight in fog" appearance (a white retinal inflammatory nidus when viewed through vitritis). This finding is seen in the image below:

Fundal examination may show a satellite lesion (a single focus of fluffy white retinitis that is associated with a pigmented scar) or vitiritis as mentioned above. Optic disc edema is also common.

Splashed tomato appearance of fundus is seen in central retinal vein occlusion and occurs due to massive retinal hemorrhages. It is seen in the image below:

Pizza pie appearance of fundus is seen in retinitis associated with cytomegalovirus (otherwise known as hemorrhagic retinitis). It is seen in the image below:

Candle wax dripping appearance of fundus is expected in sarcoidosis and occurs due to the characteristic perivascular sheathing of retinal veins. It is seen in the image below:

questions.text: A patient came to the ENT outpatient clinic with complaints of hearing loss and sensation of spinning while coughing, lifting heavy weights, and on exposure to loud sounds. He also describes that he is able to hear his eye movements and footsteps. There is a history of trauma a few weeks back. Pure-tone audiometry shows an air-bone gap. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome.

Here, the patients present with autophony (Hearing eye movements and footsteps), vertigo induced by loud sounds (Tullio's phenomenon), and Valsalva maneuvers, or by changes in pressure in the external auditory canal (Hennebert's sign). An air-bone gap in the audiometry represents conductive hearing loss.

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome occurs due to the third window effect created by the thin/ dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. It is usually diagnosed in middle-aged individuals. Etiology may be congenital or acquired from cranial trauma.

Patients present with noise or pressure-induced dizziness. Some may complain of chronic imbalance. As a result, the patient adopts avoidance of noisy environments. Also, some may have gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis. 

Nystagmus triggered by sound or pressure, where the eye movements align in the same direction as the exposed semicircular canal, is a characteristic sign. PTA shows a low-frequency conductive hearing loss. Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect, and the condition is usually treated by surgery if there are severe disabling symptoms. Else, conservative medical management is done.

Other options:

Option A: Vestibular neuritis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating, and pallor. There should be no associated cochlear symptoms like hearing loss and tinnitus, neurological symptoms, or signs of brainstem lesions. 

Option B: Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is a disorder of the inner ear caused by impaired endolymph resorption. It is characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the affected ear. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) will reveal sensorineural hearing loss. Hennebert’s sign and Tullio phenomenon are also seen in cases of Meniere's disease.

Option D: Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis willisii (better hearing in noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with difficulty in speech and swallowing. Upon examination, a lesion was found in the posterior cranial fossa affecting the hypoglossal nerve. When asked to protrude his tongue, it deviates to the right. Which muscle is likely paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The right genioglossus muscle is paralysed in the above given clinical scenario.

Actions of genioglossus muscle:

  • When both the right and left genioglossi contract, they protrude the anterior part of the tongue out of the mouth in the midline. When only one muscle contracts, it protrudes and turns the tongue to the opposite side.
  • It depresses the central part of the tongue.

Clinical considerations:

  • The genioglossi are attached to the genial tubercle present on the mandible. This prevents the tongue from sinking backwards and obstructing the respiration. Hence this muscle is known as the safety muscle of the tongue.
  • Genioglossus is the major muscle innervated by the hypoglossal nerve. In conditions affecting the hypoglossal nerve, the genioglossus muscle on that side is paralysed. In such cases, when the patient protrudes the tongue, it deviates towards the affected side due to the contraction of the muscle on the normal side.

questions.text: The x descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to _______ phase of the cardiac cycle.
questions.solution:
The x descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to the ventricular systole of the cardiac cycle.

The jugular venous pulse

  • The waves in JVP reflect the pressure changes in the right atrium.
  • The internal jugular vein is preferred because the external jugular vein is valved and not directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium.
  • a wave: Corresponds to right atrial contraction.
  • c wave: Corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction.
  • x descent: Corresponds to the atrial relaxation as the ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve.
  • v wave: Corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve.
  • y descent: Corresponds to fall in right atrial pressure during passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

questions.text: Given below is an instrument which is used to measure air humidity. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is a Sling Psychrometer, It is used to measure the humidity/ moisture content in the air.

Sling Psychrometer has 2 mercury thermometers (wet and dry) in it. The wet bulb is moistened first with distilled water and the instrument is whirled/rotated standing with the back to the sun. The reading is noted twice.

Later the dry bulb is taken up for the reading and the relative air humidity is obtained by use of suitable tables and charts.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

  • A number of thermometers which employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.
  • These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.
  • The instruments used to measure air temperature are:
    • Dry bulb thermometers:
      • These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level
    • Wet bulb thermometers
      • These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.
    • Maximum thermometer
      • This is a mercury thermometer which has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb
    • Minimum thermometer
      • The liquid in this thermometer is spirit which has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it
    • Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer
      • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
      • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
      • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available
  • Globe thermometer:
    • It is used for the direct measurement of mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
    • It has a hollow metal bulb (6 inches diameter) which has a matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
    • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.
  • Kata thermometers:
    • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
    • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
    • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient with emphysema and deranged liver enzymes was found to have alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Which of the following is a false statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can lead to hepatocellular carcinoa in some cases
It is an autosomal recessive condition
Emphysema occurs due to failure of degradation of alveoli
Liver biopsy shows periodic acid–schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant

questions.solution:
Emphysema does not occur due to the failure of degradation of alveoli and hence it is a false statement regarding the diagnosis. Usually, α1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli leading to emphysema.

The alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder of protein misfolding that occurs due to a mutation in chromosome 14 and results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. This results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema.

It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. As a consequence of the abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes, deranged liver enzymes and icterus suggestive of cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma can occur.

The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes which are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients.

questions.text: An intern commits a negligent act in the hospital. You as his senior doctor will be held responsible for the negligent act as the intern is working under you. This is explained by _____.
questions.solution:
The senior doctor is responsible for the negligent act of a junior doctor, resident, intern, or assistant working under him by vicarious liability.

Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).

When two doctors practice as partners, they are both responsible for each other's negligent acts. When 2 or more doctors independently attend a patient, each may be held liable for the negligence of others that he observes or in the ordinary course should have observed and allows it to continue without objection.

When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily loses his control over this worker and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control. This is known as borrowed servant doctrine.

Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care from the patient's part or from the attendant. This act, along with the negligent act of the doctor has contributed to the injury. If there was no contributory negligence, the injury would not have occurred. The doctor's negligence is not the direct cause of the injury. Eg. refusal to take required treatment, getting discharged against the doctor's advice, etc.

Res ipsa loquitur in Latin means "the thing speaks for itself". If an untoward result happened that is thought to be due to deviation from the normal standards of care, or negligence, then the doctor should admit the problem. The doctor should take the responsibility to explain the issue to the patient and their family, and solve the problem by either initiating treatment or transferring care. There should be no charge for additional care or for further procedures.

questions.text: A person with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-range proteinuria. Which of the following would be the most likely histological finding in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features in a patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy and nephrotic-range proteinuria are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) would be the most likely histological pattern in such patients.

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with characteristic degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells as well as effacement of foot processes.

Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis is due to entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

Classification of FSGS:

Primary

Secondary

Inherited

Idiopathic FSGS

HIV associated

Mutations in genes that encode proteins localized to the slit diaphragm

Ex: Podocin, Alpha- actin 4, TRPC6
 

Heroin addiction

  
 

Sickle cell disease

  
 

Obesity

  
 

Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g., IgA nephropathy)

  
 

Renal ablation, unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia, reflux nephropathy

  
 

Hypertensive nephropathy

  

Light microscopy: Focal segmental sclerosis and hyalinization of the glomeruli; Lipid droplets

Electron microscopy: Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes as well as focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells; no electron-dense deposits.

questions.text: What is the most important factor in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis?

choices.text: One week antibiotic therapy prior to surgery

questions.solution:
The most important factor in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis is preoperative preparation with povidone iodine. 

Postoperative endophthalmitis

Pathogens: About 90% of isolates are gram-positive and 10% gram-negative. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common.

Source of infection: Flora of the eyelids and conjunctiva are the most frequent source. Other potential sources include contaminated solutions and instruments, environmental air, and the surgeon and other operating room personnel.

Prophylaxis

  • Instillation of 5% povidone-iodine into the conjunctival fornices and leaving this undisturbed for at least 3 minutes prior to surgery.
  • Scrupulous preparation of the surgical site
  • Treatment of pre-existing infections such as blepharitis
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis
    • Intracameral cefuroxime (1 mg in 0.1 mL) injected into the anterior chamber (AC) at the end of surgery.
    • Postoperative subconjunctival injection can achieve bactericidal levels in the AC for at least 1–2 hours.
    • Preoperative topical fluoroquinolone antibiotics are frequently given in regimens from 1 hour to 3 days before surgery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding antigenic drift?

choices.text: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
It doesn’t account for the periodic epidemics of influenza
The new antigens thus formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens
Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralise the new variants

questions.solution:
Antigenic drift causes a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure.

Antigenic variation is a property of influenza viruses by which it alters the antigenic structure on its surface and thus avoids a host immune response. It is of two types - Antigenic shift and antigenic drift. 

  Antigenic shift Antigenic drift
Antigenic structure Abrupt, drastic change Gradual, sequential change 
Occurs in occurs only in Infuenza A virus Occurs in type A and to less extent in type B
Periodicity  10 - 20 years 2 - 3 years   
Epidemiological effect Pandemics and major epidemics  Periodic epidemic and sporadic cases
Genetic cause Large genetic re-assortment Point mutation
Antibodies to predecessor strains Do not neutralize the new variant Neutralizes the new variant to varying degrees

Influenza vaccine requires periodic strain change due to antigenic change in the surface glycoprotein of the virus.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever, hepatosplenomegaly and a rash. The characteristic 'owl eye' inclusion bodies are noted on further evaluation. Which of the following is the best specimen to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with fever, hepatosplenomegaly and rash along with owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in Congenital cytomegalovirus infection. Congenital CMV infection is diagnosed by detection of virus in the saliva or urine (saliva > urine), within the first two weeks of life. If culture is required then urine samples are better than saliva. PCR assays can be used to detect small amounts of CMV DNA in the urine.

Cytomegalovirus is a type of herpes virus, which causes severe disease in immunocompromised patients. In most other cases, it is inapparent and marked by prolonged latency with intermittent reactivation.

Diagnosis:

  • IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). 
  • Avidity level measured by avidity index is used to describe the percentage of IgG bound to the antigen after being treated with denaturing agents.These assays are based on the fact that low avidity IgG antibodies are present during the first few months after the infection and avidity increases over time indicating maturation of the immune response. So the presence of high avidity IgG denotes a past infection rather than a primary one. Low avidity IgG signals a primary infection within the last 3-4 months. 
  • IgM detection can be used as an indicator of acute infection, but it lacks specificity for primary infection. This is because it persists for years in some individuals and is also produced during reactivation.

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

questions.text: A statistician is working on a study about the hemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below. What is the nature of the data seen here?
questions.solution:
In the image, the tail of the distribution is towards the positive direction and thus it is a positively skewed or right-skewed distribution.

To further understand and correlate the data representation with that of a corresponding box and whisker plot, have a look at the following images:

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (b) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (c) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (a) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an element of primary healthcare?

choices.text: Adequate supply of safe water and basic sanitation

questions.solution:
The elements of primary health care include:

  1. Adequate supply of safe water and basic sanitation
  2. Providing essential drugs
  3. Prevention of locally endemic diseases

Primary health care refers to essential health care made universally available to individuals and acceptable to them, through their full participation and at a cost the community and country can afford.

Use of appropriate technology and ensuring community participation are principles/pillars of Primary Health Care.

questions.text: You are posted in the oncology ward and you are evaluating the patients. In which one of these given malignancies, brain metastasis is unlikely to happen?
questions.solution:
In prostate cancer, metastasis to the brain is unlikely to happen.

Metastatic brain tumours account for a major number of all intracranial space-occupying lesions and the brain is a site for metastasis from several common primary cancers such as those arising in the lungs, breasts, skin, kidneys, and the GIT. However, although prostate cancer is also one of the common tumours, it is unlikely to metastasize to the brain and is more commonly associated with bone metastases.

Batson venous plexus is a valveless vertebral venous plexus communicating with the prostatic venous plexus. Carcinoma of the prostate metastasizes to the bone usually by the bloodstream through this Batson plexus. The bones most frequently involved are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae. The femoral head, ribcage and skull are other common sites. Other routes of spread of prostate carcinoma are local spread to the seminal vesicles, bladder neck, trigone, and lymphatic spread.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignancy in men above 65 years. The clinical features of prostate cancer are bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, arthritis, anaemia, and renal failure. Per rectal examination reveals a hard, nodular, irregularly indurated gland. 

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is useful in assessing the follow-up. PSA >10 ng/mL is suggestive of cancer and levels >35 ng/mL are diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. The prostatic biopsy is indicated when there is a raised PSA level or suspicion of prostate cancer.

Localized cancer is treated by radical prostatectomy and radiation therapy, while in advanced cancer palliative and hormone ablation should be carried out. 

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text:
Match the type of hyperlipoproteinemias in column A with the underlying defects present in column B. (LDL-low-density lipoprotein, VLDL- very low density lipoprotein)
Column A Column B
1. Type I a. Defective LDL receptors
2. Type IIa b. Overproduction of VLDL
3. Type III c. Hepatic lipase deficiency
4. Type IV d. Defective apo E
  e. Lipoprotein lipase or Apo C-II deficiency
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-e, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b. 

Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia : Deficiency in lipoprotein lipase (LPL), leads to hyperchylomicronemia(Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia). This condition results from defects in LPL or apo C-II, causing elevated levels of chylomicrons and VLDL, with decreased levels of LDL and HDL. Patients often develop eruptive xanthomas but are not at risk for coronary artery disease. However, they are at an increased risk of acute pancreatitis due to extremely high triglyceride levels, which can also cause a milky appearance in the plasma.

Type IIa Hyperlipoproteinemia : Defective LDL receptor points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia(type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia). This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia : It is also known as broad β-disease, remnant removal disease, or familial dysbetalipoproteinemia. Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is caused by a defective ApoE that mediated the removal of lipoprotein remnants. Clinical features include hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis. There is an increase in remnant chylomicrons, remnant VLDL (i.e.Intermediate-density lipoprotein), cholesterol, and triglyceride levels. Fibrates are effective in treating patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia.

Type IV Hyperlipoproteinemia : It is also known as Familial hypertriacylglycerolemia. It is caused due to Overproduction of VLDL. There is an increase in Chylomicrons and VLDL and is commonly associated with coronary heart disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, obesity, alcoholism, and administration of progestational hormones. 

Dyslipoproteinemias  
Hypolipoproteinemias 
Name Defect

Features
Abetalipoproteinemia Defective loading of apo B with lipid

No chylomicrons, VLDL, or LDL formation

Intestinal Malabsorption

Treated by administration of large doses of vitamin E. 

Familial α-lipoprotein deficiency 

Tangier disease 

Fish-eye disease 

Apo A-I deficiencies 

 Low or near absent HDL is seen in all

Low LDL

No increased risk of coronary artery disease

Elevated LDL levels and hypercholesterolemia, resulting in atherosclerosis and coronary disease

Familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia (broad β-disease, remnant removal disease, familial dysbetalipoproteinemia

Hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis are seen

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the corresponding antimicrobials are true except?

choices.text: Dapsone inhibits the action of dihydropteroate synthase
Nitazoxanide is useful in giardiasis and cryptosporidiosis
Vancomycin acts by inhibiting transglycosylase and prevents elongation
Amikacin acts on the 30s subunit and is effective against anaerobes

questions.solution:
Amikacin acts on the 30s subunit but is weak and not very effective against anaerobes.

Amikacin belongs to the aminoglycosides group of drugs. They are bactericidal inhibitors of protein synthesis and are used primarily to treat infections caused by aerobic gram-negative bacteria. It is not used as a monotherapy to treat gram-positive infections and is usually combined with another potent agent.

Other options:

Option A -  The mechanism of action of dapsone is the inhibition of folic acid synthesis. Dapsone is a structural analogue of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway. It is weakly bactericidal and can cause mild hemolysis, and rarely anaemia or psychosis.

Option B: Nitazoxanide is an oral, synthetic, broad-spectrum antiparasitic agent. The FDA has approved its usage for the treatment of cryptosporidiosis and giardiasis in adults and immunocompetent children.

Option C: Vancomycin is a glycopeptide and inhibits the synthesis of the cell wall. It acts by inhibiting transglycosylase and preventing elongation. It is useful against a range of gram-positive microbes and is effective in the treatment of MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) strains.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD with dry, scaly dermatitis. On evaluation, he had a deficiency of essential fatty acids. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of the essential fatty acid, linoleic acid, is likely to have caused this child's presentation of dry and scaly dermatitis.

Essential fatty acid (EFA) refers to polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) required for biological processes but is not synthesized by the body.

The two essential fatty acids in humans are as follows:

  • Linoleic acid (Omega 6): It is the precursor of arachidonic acid
  • α-Linolenic acid (Omega 3): It is the precursor of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid.

Clinical Significance of PUFA and EFA

  1. PUFAs are used for esterification and excretion of cholesterol.
  2. Deficiency of EFA causes acanthocytosis, hyperkeratosis, acrodermatitis, and hypercholesterolemia.
  3. EFA deficiency is connected with acrodermatitis enteropathica, hepatorenal syndrome, and CNS manifestations.
  4. Elevated PUFA levels are seen in Zellweger’s syndrome.
  5. DHA levels in the blood are low in patients with retinitis pigmentosa.
  6. Trans fatty acids will compete with EFAs and may increase the EFA deficiency and decrease the fluidity of membranes.

Other options:

Options A & B: Oleic and palmitoleic acids are non-essential fatty acids. They can be synthesized in the body naturally. 

Option D: Arachidonic acid is non-essential fatty acid as it can be synthesized from linoleic acid.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with pneumonic plague. Which of the following droplet precautions are recommended in this condition?

choices.text: 48 hours after initiation of effective antibiotic therapy
96 hours after initiation of effective antibiotic therapy
24 hours after initiation of effective antibiotic therapy
1 week after onset of cough or fever

questions.solution:
Droplets precaution for a patient with pneumonic plague is recommended until 48 hours after initiation of effective antibiotic therapy.
