questions.text: A 20-year-old woman has complaints of reduced hearing on her right side. You perform a diagnostic test using the following instrument. What is the name of this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image is of a Digital audiometer.

An audiometer is an electronic device which produces pure tones, the intensity of which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. Air conduction thresholds are measured for tones of 125, 250, 500, 1000, 2000, 4000 and 8000 Hz and bone conduction thresholds for 250, 500, 1000, 2000 and 4000 Hz. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing impairment at that frequency. It is charted in the form of a graph called audiogram.

The threshold of bone conduction is a measure of cochlear function. The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A–B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness.

Uses:

  • It is a measure of threshold of hearing by air and bone conduction and thus the degree and type of hearing loss.
  • A record can be kept for future reference.
  • Audiogram is essential for prescription of hearing aid.
  • Helps to find degree of handicap for medicolegalpurposes.
  • Helps to predict speech reception threshold.

questions.text: Hassall’s corpuscles are derived from which pharyngeal pouch?
questions.solution:
Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) are derived from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch. 

The 3rd pouch gives rise to the thymus in the ventral part and the inferior parathyroid gland in the dorsal part. The thymus then moves away from the pharyngeal wall in a caudal and medial direction, pulling the inferior parathyroid with it. It reaches the anterior part of the thorax, where it fuses with its counterpart from the opposite side. 

The endodermal cells of the thymus get invaded by the vascular mesoderm, which contains numerous lymphoblasts. Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) are derived from the endoderm of the 3rd pouch. The thymocytes are derived from bone marrow and the cytoreticulum.

questions.text: A 30-year old patient comes to the hospital with complaints of blood-tinged nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows a pink polypoidal mass in the right nose and the same is biopsied. The image given below is the histological slide of the specimen. Treatment of choice for this condition is?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathology showing several sporangia is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis. Surgical management (Excision of the lesion with cauterisation of the base ), is the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patients clinically present with blood-tinged nasal discharge, and pink polypoidal mass in the nose.

Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.

It is treated by completely excising the mass with a diathermy knife followed by cauterization of the base.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text: During a neck dissection, a surgeon accidentally damages the hypoglossal nerve. Which neck triangle is likely being dissected?
questions.solution:
The surgeon has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve, which has its major course in the carotid triangle.

The hypoglossal nerve leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It then descends to the carotid triangle. Here, in the carotid triangle, the nerve makes a loop lateral to the internal and external carotid arteries. The nerve then ascends to the digastric triangle, reaches further up supplying the muscles of the tongue.

Contents of the carotid triangle:

  • Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
  • Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Spinal part of the accessory
  • Sympathetic chain
  • Ansa cervicalis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about chaperones and protein misfolding is true?

choices.text: These proteins generally bind to the hydrophilic region of unfolded proteins and prevent their aggregation.
Calnexin and Calreticulin are two calcium-binding chaperones that are membrane-bound.
Hsp 70 is a promising chaperone that can be employed in the treatment of such disorders of proteostasis deficiencies.
Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) antigens are predominantly bound by Calreticulin.

questions.solution:
Chaperones assist in protein folding. They are a type of heat-shock protein weighing 70 kDa (hsp70).

Mechanism of action: 

  • They bind to the short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids of an extended polypeptide.
  • They effectively shield the new polypeptide being synthesized from aggregating, to provide them an opportunity to form appropriate secondary structures.
  • In instances where a protein is thermodynamically trapped in a misfolded dead-end form, the chaperones can rescue the protein by unfolding these hydrophobic ends, providing the protein a second chance to fold productively.

Properties of chaperones:

  • Many are heat shock proteins
  • Some are inducible by conditions that cause the unfolding of newly synthesized proteins
  • Bind to hydrophobic region of unfolded proteins and prevent their aggregation
  • Detect misfolded or otherwise defective proteins
  • Most chaperones show associated ATPase activity
  • Found in the cytosol, mitochondria, and the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum

Some of the important enzymes and Chaperones in the ER responsible for proper protein folding:

  • BiP (immunoglobulin heavy-chain binding protein)
  • GRP94 (glucose-regulated protein)
  • Calnexin - calcium-binding membrane-bound protein involved in post glycosylated retention of proteins in ER till proper folding completes. Binds to MHC antigens. 
  • Calreticulin - similar to calnexin except that it is not protein-bound. 
  • PDI (protein disulfide isomerase) - reshuffles disulfide bonds. 
  • PPI (a peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase) - accelerates the folding of proline-containing proteins. 

Use of Chaperones in therapy:

  • Lysosomal storage diseases (Tay-Sachs disease)
  • Hsp 70 is a promising chaperone that can be employed in the treatment of such disorders of proteostasis deficiencies
  • Geldanamycin is an antibiotic known to activate Heat shock proteins

ER Stress response:

The unfolded protein response, also known as the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response, occurs in response to the accumulation of the unfolded or misfolded proteins in the ER due to the inherited mutations or stresses.

If a protein fails to appropriately fold or oligomerize, then it accumulates in the ER, thereby initiating the unfolded protein response. The ER stress causes decreased production of proteins and activation of the increased production of the chaperones that play a role in refolding the proteins. The senescent or denatured or misfolded proteins are degraded by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. If the cell fails to adapt to the increased ER stress, apoptosis may occur. 

These could result in disorders as shown below.

questions.text: A patient suffering from hyperthyroidism is administered a drug that acts by inhibiting the release of thyroid hormone. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Potassium iodide inhibits the release of the thyroid hormone.

Iodides of sodium and potassium and Lugol's iodine act by inhibiting thyroid hormone release. Hence, they are also called thyroid constipating agents.  They are the fastest-acting agents.

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-thyroid drugs

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting iodide trapping:

  • Thiocyanates
  • Perchlorates
  • Nitrates

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

questions.text: A 55-year-old math teacher presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset impairment of mathematical ability. Which of the following areas of the brain is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Acalculia is an impairment of mathematical ability and occurs due to an impairment of the left frontal lobe, the categorical hemisphere.

In our human body, one hemisphere is specialised for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere or dominant hemisphere) and another is specialised for visuospatial relations (the representational hemisphere or the non-dominant hemisphere).

Lesions in the representational hemisphere lead to:

  1. Astereognosis—the inability to identify objects by feeling them
  2. Agnosia- inability to recognize objects by a particular sensory modality even though the sensory modality itself is intact. This commonly occurs due to a lesion in the parietal lobe. Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognise faces.
  3. Unilateral inattention and neglect- Patients neglect one-half of their bodies. It occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule.

Lesions in the categorical hemisphere lead to

  1. Broca's aphasia is caused due to an injury in the inferior frontal gyrus. It causes nonfluent aphasia. Affected individuals have slow speech and difficulty in generating verbal or written words.
  2. Wernicke's aphasia is caused due to a lesion in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It produces a type of fluent aphasia in which speech itself is normal but it is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense. The patient also fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words, so other aspects of the use of language are compromised.
  3. Anomic aphasia- When a lesion damages the angular gyrus in the categorical hemisphere without affecting Wernicke or Broca areas, there is no difficulty with speech or the understanding of auditory information. However there is trouble understanding written language or pictures because visual information is not processed and transmitted to the Wernicke area.
  4. Global aphasia- In this, both understanding and speaking is impaired. It is also non-fluent aphasia.
  5. Acalculia- Impairment of mathematical ability. Occurs due to an impairment to the left frontal lobe.

There are two parietal lobes - the dominant side and the non-dominant side.

  • The functions of the dominant side of the parietal lobe are calculation, language, planned movement, appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia.
  • The function of the non-dominant side is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

The somatic sensory area and related parts of the posterior parietal lobe project to the premotor cortex. Some of these neurons are concerned with aiming and manipulating the hands at an object, whereas other neurons are concerned with hand-eye coordination. Neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

questions.text: The lung compliance of a 40-year-old patient with shortness of breath has been compared to that of a normal person in the pressure-volume curve below. What is the likely diagnosis based on this chart?
questions.solution:
The interpretation of the above pressure-volume curve shows that the patient has increased lung compliance, making the likely diagnosis of pulmonary emphysema. 

Compliance is the tendency for tissue to resume its original position after an applied force has been removed.

After an expiration during quiet breathing, the lungs have a tendency to collapse and the chest wall has a tendency to expand. The interaction between the recoil of the lungs and the recoil of the chest can be measured through a spirometer and a curve of airway pressure plotted against volume is the pressure-volume curve of the total respiratory system (Ptr).

Compliance of the lung and chest wall is measured as the slope of the PTR curve, or, as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure (ΔV/ΔP). 

  • The curve is shifted downwards when compared to normal in case of decreased compliance. Eg. pulmonary edema, and interstitial pulmonary fibrosis due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance. Eg. emphysema, normal aging lungs due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched).

 

Increased compliance seen in emphysema is due to - 

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: Which of the following is not regarded as a grievous type of injury?

choices.text: Permanent loss of sight in one eye

questions.solution:
Among the given injuries, temporary disfigurement of the face is not regarded as a grievous injury.

Grievous hurt or injury are those injuries that are inflicted voluntarily to another person and comprise of any of the following eight clauses given below:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation. (option A). Examples are castration, cutting away of the penis, etc.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent loss of sight of either eye. (option B)
  • Clause 3 — Permanent loss of hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth. (Option D)
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 20 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

IPC Section 320 defines grievous injury. Voluntarily causing grievous hurt is punishable under section 322 IPC. Punishment for grievous hurt is defined under section 325 IPC. The convict shall be punished by imprisonment for a term extending to 7 years and also a fine.

Other important points related to the injury are:

IPC section

Section it deals with

Punishment

324

Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons.

Up to 3 years of imprisonment or fine or both

325

Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt

Up to 7 years of imprisonment and fine

326

Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means

Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

326A

Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid

Minimum 10 years imprisonment, extended up to life imprisonment and fine

326B

Voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid

Minimum 5 years imprisonment and fine

questions.text: During a clinical assessment, a neurologist stimulates a specific structure to evaluate the sensory supply from a cranial nerve. Which cranial nerve's sensory function is being assessed by touching the highlighted structure in the image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given sagittal section of the head and neck is the uvula. The sensory supply by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)  is tested in this case.

Innervation of the soft palate:

  • General sensation - Lesser palatine nerve(branch of maxillary nerve) and the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve 
  • Taste sensation - Lesser palatine nerve.
  • Secretomotor supply -Lesser palatine nerve via postganglionic fibres from the pterygopalatine ganglion.
  • Motor supply - Pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve (except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

Pharyngeal plexus: The nerve supply of the pharynx is mainly from the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve form it. (It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion) The vagus nerve provides the motor supply and the glossopharyngeal nerve provides the sensory supply.

Nerve supply by glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Sensory fibres to the uvula, tympanic cavity, pharyngotympanic tube, tonsils, fauces, nasopharynx, and posterior third of the tongue.
  • Motor fibres to the stylopharyngeus muscle
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland
  • Gustatory fibres for the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

Nerve supply by the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve:

  • All the muscles of the soft palate (except tensor veli palatini - supplied by mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve)
  • All the muscles of the pharynx(except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

questions.text: The sites of synthesis of  glycosaminoglycans is _______
questions.solution:
The sites of synthesis of glycosaminoglycans (GAG) are endoplasmic reticulum and golgi apparatus.

Synthesis of GAG:

  • Synthesis of the core proteins: Endoplasmic reticulum
  • Biosynthesis of glycosaminoglycan chains and their subsequent modifications: Golgi apparatus

The biochemically important GAGs are as follows:

  • Hyaluronic acid
  • Chondroitin sulfate
  • Keratan sulfate
  • Heparin
  • Heparan sulfate
  • Dermatan sulfate

Note: Hyaluronic acid is the only GAG that is not synthesized by the golgi apparatus. It is formed at the plasma membrane.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female has been fasting. Which of the following cycles provides a major source of glucose for the body from skeletal muscle breakdown in such conditions?
questions.solution:
In a fasting state, the Cahill cycle also known as glucose-alanine cycle provides the major source of glucose for the body from muscle breakdown of amino acids.

In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from muscle as it is the major substrate for gluconeogenesis. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Muscle glycogen cannot be utilized directly from the muscle as muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase essential for the breakdown of glucose-6-phosphate into glucose.

Other options :

Option A: The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle / glucose-lactate cycle. Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and erythrocytes. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. 

Option C: Krebs cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins because glucose, fatty acids, and most amino acids are metabolized to acetyl-CoA or intermediates of the cycle.

Option D: Rapoport-lumbering cycle takes place in the red blood cells (RBC). Here 1, 3- Bisphosphoglycerate kinase is bypassed, no ATPs are produced in that step. Only 2 ATPs are generated by the pyruvate kinase step and 2 ATPs are utilized in the steps catalyzed by hexokinase and Phosphofructokinase - 1. So this pathway yields no net generation of ATP from glycolysis.

questions.text: A young man has a known history of Meneire's disease. He works at a car showroom and has episodes of vertigo when the cars honk too loudly. This symptom is best described as:
questions.solution:
This symptom is best described as the Tullio phenomenon.

Tullio phenomenon describes the vertiginous episodes associated with exposure to loud noise in a patient with Meniere's disease. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is a disorder of the inner ear caused by impaired endolymph resorption. It is characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and sensation of fullness in the affected ear.

The treatment of Meniere's disease includes:

  • General measures like cessation of smoking, a low salt diet and avoiding excessive intake of water, lifestyle changes to avoid stress and avoiding activities like scuba diving which require good body balance
  • Management of an acute attack by the administration of intravenous fluids and electrolytes, vestibular sedatives like promethazine, dimenhydrinate and prochlorperazine, vasodilators like carbogen that also improve labyrinthine circulation, diazepam to suppress the activity of medial vestibular nucleus and bed rest.
  • Management of chronic phase by administration of vasodilators like betahistine that increase labyrinthine blood flow, vestibular sedatives like prochlorperazine, diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide to control recurrent attacks and propantheline bromide, an anticholinergic agent. Chemical labyrinthectomy by intratympanic gentamicin therapy is also done.
  • Surgical treatment by conservative procedures like decompression of endolymphatic sac, endolymphatic shunt operation, sacculotomy or Fick's operation, the section of vestibular nerve and destruction of the vestibular labyrinth by ultrasound. Destructive procedures like labyrinthectomy are done when the cochlear function is not serviceable. Intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy, also known as Meniett device therapy helps relieve the symptoms.

Other options- 

Option A: Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. 

Option C: Lermoyez syndrome includes symptoms of Meniere's disease seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

Option D: Vestibular hydrops includes typical episodes of vertigo while cochlear function remaining intact.

questions.text: Which of the following study designs is used to calculate the point prevalence of a disease?
questions.solution:
The study design that can be used to calculate the point prevalence of a disease is a Cross-sectional study.

The point prevalence of a disease is defined as the number of all current cases at a point in time. It can be calculated using cross-sectional studies. A cross-sectional study Is an observational study used to calculate a disease's distribution and prevalence. Prevalence helps to estimate the magnitude of health/ disease problems in the community and identify potential high-risk populations.

Other options:

Options A & B: A cohort study is an analytical study involving the follow-up of a cohort (a group of people) with risk factors to check if they develop an outcome or disease. It can be used to calculate incidence.

Option D: A randomized control trial is an experimental study in which an intervention is given to a group of patients participating in the study and compared to another group of patients with similar characteristics who are not given that intervention to be studied. It is used to calculate the effect of an intervention.

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A child was brought by her parents with the given findings. Which of the following describes the wound shown here?
questions.solution:
The wound shown in the image is best described as an abrasion wound on the hand.

Abrasions are superficial wounds produced due to the destruction of the epidermis. Though exact age cannot be determined, based on healing and appearance of the wound, an estimated time can be given.

Abrasion types:

  • Linear abrasions (scratches): caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin
    • Ex: nail, thorn, the point of sword or knife
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.
    • known as brush burns; are the most common type of abrasions
    • Ex: fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents
  • Imprint abrasions (patterned abrasions): caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement
    • Ex: fingernail, tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): are caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis.
    • Ex: ligature marks around the neck in hanging,

Other options:

Option A: A bruise or a contusion occurs due to blunt trauma that causes rupture of underlying blood vessels and extravasation of the blood into surrounding tissues. A fresh bruise is usually tender and is slightly raised above the surface of the skin. It has a lighter colour in the center because the extravasated blood is pushed outward by the impact of the trauma. A picture of a bruise is shown below:

Option B: A puncture wound is a stab wound that is produced when force is delivered along the long axis of a narrow or pointed object such as a knife, dagger, or sword into the soft tissues of the body. An image of a puncture wound is shown below:

Option D: A scald burn is an injury that occurs when the skin comes in contact with any liquid at a temperature above 60ºC or steam. Immediate redness is observed at the site followed by blistering. With the removal of the blistered skin, a pink raw surface is observed which later becomes brownish, hard, and dry. An image of a scald burn is shown below:

questions.text: An ENT resident uses the following method to examine a patient in OPD. Which of the following structures will not be visible to him?
questions.solution:
The image shows posterior rhinoscopy examination. Vallecula will not be visualized in this method of examination, but it can be visualized on indirect laryngoscopy.

St. Clair Thompson mirror is the other name for posterior rhinoscopy Mirror. It has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

The structures seen in posterior rhinoscopy are:

  • Adenoids
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates
  • Opening of the eustachian tube
  • The posterior border of the nasal septum
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller
  • Torus tubarius
  • The upper surface of the soft palate

The pathologies we can look for using posterior rhinoscopy are:

  • Choanal polyp or atresia
  • Hypertrophy of posterior ends of inferior turbinates.
  • Discharge in the middle meatus: Postnasal discharge seen in cases of sinusitis, can only be seen on posterior rhinoscopy.

Indirect laryngoscopy is done using a laryngeal mirror. It is straight without any bends with a mirror at end.

Structures seen during indirect laryngoscopy:

  • Larynx: Epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, arytenoids, cuneiform and corniculate cartilages, glossoepiglottic folds, pharyngoepiglottic folds, aryepiglottic fold, true and false vocal cords, anterior commissure, posterior commissure, subglottis and rings of trachea.
  • Laryngopharynx: Both piriform fossae, postcricoid region, posterior wall of laryngopharynx.
  • Oropharynx: Base of tongue, lingual tonsils, valleculae, medial and lateral glossoepiglottic folds.

questions.text: A baby is born with hydrocephalus, intraparenchymal calcifications, and chorioretinitis. The mother is suffering from which teratogenic infection?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a newborn with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications is suggestive of congenital toxoplasmosis.

Sabin Feldman dye test is done for the diagnosis of Toxoplasma gondii. The test is based on the presence of certain antibodies that prevent methylene blue dye from entering the cytoplasm of Toxoplasma organisms.

Procedure: Patient serum is treated with Toxoplasma trophozoites and complements which act as activators, and then incubated. After incubation, methylene blue is added. If anti-toxo antibodies are present in the serum, these antibodies are activated by complements and lyse the parasite membrane, thus, Toxoplasma trophozoites are not stained. This implies a positive result. If there are no antibodies, trophozoites with intact membranes are stained and appear blue under a microscope (negative result). The test may give false positive reactions in Sarcocystis, Trichomonas vaginalis, and Trypanosoma lewisii infections.

Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when a pregnant woman transmits the infection to the fetus transplacentally or at the time of vaginal delivery. The severity of the disease in the neonate is greater if the woman gets infected early in her pregnancy.

The classical triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications can be seen in infected neonates. Other possible features include small size for gestational age, prematurity, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hydrops fetalis, and perinatal death.

Other Options:

Option B: CMV is the most common congenital infection. The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Option C: Sensory neural deafness, PDA, salt pepper appearance on retinoscopy is suggestive of Congenital rubella syndrome.

Option D: Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly, jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands and feet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions.

questions.text: Sign of pathological myopia is_____.
questions.solution:
Temporal myopic crescent is a feature of pathological myopia.

It is a white crescent at the temporal border of the disc.

Signs of pathological myopia include the following:

  • Prominent eyeballs
  • Large cornea
  • Deep anterior chamber (AC)
  • Fundus picture
    • Large, pale optic disc with the temporal myopic crescent
    • Degenerative changes in retina and choroid
  • Foster Fuch's spots
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy
  • Posterior staphyloma
  • Degenerative changes in the vitreous—Posterior vitreous detachment

questions.text: What is the function of tubuloglomerular feedback?
questions.solution:
Tubuloglomerular feedback regulates the Glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Tubuloglomerular feedback is responsible for changing the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in response to the amount of fluid that reaches the distal tubule. The sensor for this response is the macula densa. The amount of sodium and chloride entering the macula densa cells is a proxy for the amount of fluid delivered to the distal tubule. Increased sodium delivery causes an increase in the activity of Na+, K+ ATPase and resulting ATP hydrolysis leads to the formation of more adenosine. This adenosine acts on adenosine A1 receptors on the macula densa cells to cause calcium release, which causes afferent arteriolar constriction. Increased sodium delivery to the distal tubule will also decrease the release of renin and consequently the formation of angiotensin II. This will finally result in mesangial cell relaxation. 

The GFR is proportional to the Kf (glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient), which depends on capillary permeability and the effective filtration surface area. The filtration surface area can be altered by the contraction or relaxation of the mesangial cells. Angiotensin II is an important factor causing mesangial cell contraction. This decreases the available surface area and the GFR. This causes less sodium to be filtered and more of it to be retained in the body, thus bringing the body fluid volume towards normal. 

Another mechanism that is responsible for the regulation of renal blood flow and GFR is the myogenic mechanism. When there is an excessive stretch of the renal vessel wall due to an increased amount of fluid, there is vascular smooth muscle contraction due to calcium entry. This prevents undue increases in renal blood flow and GFR when the arterial pressure is high.

questions.text: Which of the following types of fish cannot be used in biological control?
questions.solution:
Cyclops is a crustacean (omnivorous copepod), which belongs to the phylum Arthropoda. It is not a fish. However, the cyclops can also feed on larval stages of some mosquito species, and can be used in biological control.

The larvivorous fishes that can be used for biological control include:

  • Gambusia affinis
  • Lebister reticulatus (Barbados Millions)
  • Poecilia

questions.text: Which of the following postmortem changes is not a feature of normal decomposition?

choices.text: Discoloration of the superficial blood vessels

questions.solution:
Saponification or adipocere is a postmortem change which is not a feature of normal decomposition.

It is characterized by the formation of a waxy, greasy, and whitish substance with a sweet, rancid odor. it resembles the consistency of soap. The pattern of distribution includes areas of fatty tissues in the dead body. 

Adipocere consists primarily of fatty acids that are produced due to postmortem hydrolysis and the hydrogenation of body fats. It is a water-dependent process that involves the conversion of unsaturated liquid fats to saturated solid fats. 

Medicolegal importance is as follows:

  • It is the surest sign of death
  • It gives a rough estimate of the time since death and
  • The cause of death can be identified. In the face, the features are well preserved and therefore used in identification. 

Other options:

Option A: Right iliac fossa discoloration is the first external sign of decomposition, and is due to the action of C.welchii in the ileocecal portion of the gastrointestinal tract. Bacterially produced hydrogen sulfide combines with hemoglobin to give rise to sulphmethemoglobin which causes discoloration.

Option B and C: Subsequently, bacterial dissemination takes place through the blood vessels causing similar discoloration of the superficial blood vessels. A linear branching pattern is formed known as marbling.

questions.text: An young male with erectile dysfunction was treated with the drug alprostadil. This drug is also used for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Alprostadil is used for temporarily maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates and it is also indicated in patients not responding to phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors (sildenafil, tadalafil, etc) eg. patients with neurogenic and psychogenic erectile dysfunction.

Alprostadil is a natural prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog. PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of smooth muscle. It is available as an intraurethral suppository and intracavernosal injection. Alprostadil is also used in the treatment of critical limb ischemia, and Raynaud's phenomenon. Treatment with alprostadil results in an improvement in ulcers, pain, and limb salvage rates in critical limb ischemia patients.

Side effects of alprostadil include pain, bruising, and priapism. If priapism occurs, the patient will need urgent medical attention, which might include aspiration of blood, surgical shunt, or intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine for cavernosal vasoconstriction.

Other Prostaglandins (PG) analogues:

PGE1: Misoprostol is approved for the termination of pregnancy, and the prevention of NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.
PGE2: Dinoprostone is used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and as abortifacients in the second trimester of pregnancy. (Option D)
PGI2: Epoprostenol improves symptoms and delays the need for lung or heart-lung transplantation in pulmonary artery hypertension. Iloprost and Treprostinil used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension.
PGF2α: Carboprost is used to induce second-trimester abortions and to control postpartum hemorrhage. Latanoprost is a long-acting PGF2α derivative, used for glaucoma. (Option B) Similar prostanoids with ocular hypotensive effects include bimatoprost, tafluprost, and travoprost.

Other option(s):

Option A: Prostaglandin analogues are not indicated in the treatment of systemic hypertension.

questions.text:
A patient comes to you with vitamin D deficiency. You advise the patient to take a walk under sufficient sunlight everyday. What is the correct sequence of products formed during vitamin D synthesis?
  1. 7-dehydrocholesterol
  2. Cholecalciferol
  3. 25-hydroxycholecalciferol
  4. 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of products formed during vitamin D synthesis is 1-2-3-4.

Vitamin D is obtained by synthesis in the skin with adequate sunlight exposure or dietary supplementation. It helps in regulating calcium absorption and homeostasis. Deficiency results in rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults and is a common problem in areas with inadequate sunlight.

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is:

  1. Skin: 7-dehydrocholesterol is nonenzymatically converted to previtamin D on exposure to ultraviolet light. It is converted to cholecalciferol, which then enters the bloodstream.
  2. Liver: Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to form 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol), which is bound to a vitamin D-binding globulin and released into the bloodstream. This is the main storage form of vitamin D. 
  3. Kidney: 25-hydroxyvitamin D is further hydroxylated to form 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). This is the biologically active form of vitamin D. In some cases, it can also undergo 24-hydroxylation to form an inactive metabolite called 24,25-dihydroxyvitamin D.

The steps of vitamin D synthesis are summarized below.

Related Pearl: Fat-soluble vitamins

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is sweating not seen?
questions.solution:
Sweating is present in all of the given conditions except classic heatstroke.

Heat stroke/thermic fever/heat hyperpyrexia is characterized by a raised rectal temperature of more than 41°C. 

There is a loss of thermoregulatory function and failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism.

Heatstroke can be of two types:

  • Classic heatstroke (CHS)is seen in those with chronic diseases that predispose them to heat-related illnesses. 
  • Exertional heat stroke(EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. T

Patients usually present with a sudden collapse. The skin is dry, flushed, and hot. Sweating is absent in CHS but present in about 50% of cases of EHS. Dry skin in the presence of hyperpyrexia is virtually pathognomonic. Tachypnea (rapid Kussmaul type of breathing), tachycardia, hypotension, and widened pulse pressure are other findings.

CNS dysfunction signs include delirium, coma, and convulsions. Thermal cardiomyopathy and heat-related reversible increase in cardiac biomarker levels are also seen. The ECG may display tachyarrhythmias, nonspecific ST-T wave changes, and heat-related ischemia or infarction. 

Other complications include rhabdomyolysis, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and multiorgan failure.

Classic heat stroke Exertional heat stroke
Older patients Younger patient
Predisposing health factors/medications Healthy condition
Epidemiology (heat waves) Sporadic cases
Sedentary Exercising
Anhidrosis (possible) Diaphoresis (common)
CNS dysfunction Myocardial/hepatic injury
Oliguria Acute renal failure
Coagulopathy (mild) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
Mild lactic acidosis Marked lactic acidosis
Mild creatinine kinase elevation Rhabdomyolysis
Normoglycemia/Calcaemia Hypoglycemia/Calcemia
Normokalemia Hyperkalemia

Management of heat stroke is as follows:

  • Rapid cooling must be initiated as soon as possible 
  • Continuous monitoring with a rectal thermistor (flexible thermometer)
  • Fluid resuscitation, as determined by the patient's volume status, urine output, and cardiopulmonary function
  • Correction of electrolyte and metabolic abnormalities (hyponatremia and hypoglycemia)
There is no role of antipyretics in the control of environmentally induced hyperthermia. They also exacerbate the complications (acute kidney injury, hepatic failure, DIC).

Hyperthermic anhydrosis / Desert syndrome - The symptoms are similar to those of heat exhaustion. After many days of intense generalised sweating, all areas of the body below the neck abruptly stop sweating, but the face and neck continue to perspire. This is due to the hyperkeratotic plugging of sweat glands causing the functional failure of the sweat gland below the neck. 

Other options:

Options A and B: Heat syncope/ heat prostration/ heat exhaustion refers to collapse without any elevation of body temperature. Thermoregulatory mechanisms and CNS functions are maintained. It is precipitated by muscular exercise and unsuitable clothing following prolonged exposure to heat. There is extreme exhaustion with peripheral vascular collapse with scanty sweating. 

Option D: Heat cramps are painful muscle spasms caused by the loss of water and salt in high temperatures due to profuse sweating.

questions.text: Shake test is done to check ______.
questions.solution:
The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines that are sensitive to freezing temperatures.

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms does not have the appearance as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows characteristic bipolar staining giving a safety pin appearance. Clostridium difficile does not show bipolar staining.

In smears stained with Giemsa or methylene blue, the following organisms show bipolar staining with two ends densely stained and the central area clear.

  • Yersinia pestis
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahemolyticus
  • Calymmatobacterium granulomatis/ Klebsiella granulomatis/ 
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-week old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age.

Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of  severe laryngomalacia include:

  • Difficulty feeding
  • Increased effort in breathing
  • Poor weight gain 
  • Pauses in the breathing 
  • Frequent spitting up

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding antrochoanal polyp?

choices.text: It is more common in older adults
It is allergic in origin and recurrence is common
It usually arises from the maxillary sinus
It is usually multiple and bilateral

questions.solution:
Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoid masse of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum, comes out of it, and grows backwards to the choana and nasal cavity and may hang below the soft palate.

It is usually infective in origin. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults.  

  Antrochoanal Polyp Ethmoidal Polyp
Age Young Adults
Etiology Infective Allergic / Multifactorial
Numer Single Multiple
Site Unilateral Bilateral
Origin Maxillary sinus Ethmoidal Sinus, uncinate process, middle turbinate and middle meatus
Growth Grows posteriorly towards the choana. May hang back behind the soft palate in the pharynx Grows anteriorly towards the nares
Appearance Trilobed with antral, nasal and choanal parts.  Small and grape-like masses
Recurrence Uncommon Common
Treatment Endoscopic sinus surgery Endoscopic sinus surgery

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies the type of cell junction within the blood testis barrier that can cross it from the bloodstream?
questions.solution:
The cell junctions within the blood testis barrier allowed to enter from the bloodstream are the tight junctions.

Sertoli cells form tight junctions with each other, forming a protective barrier known as the blood-testes barrier, which separates the testes from the bloodstream. This barrier selectively allows certain substances, such as testosterone, to pass through while preventing harmful substances that could potentially harm the maturing sperm. Important functions of the blood testes barrier are as follows:

  • It prevents the passing of large molecules from interstitial tissue and basal compartment to the tubular lumen.
  • It helps in maintaining the composition of the tubular fluid.
  • It protects the developing sperm from immunological attack and blood-borne noxious agents.

In the given image:

1- basal lamina, 2- spermatogonia, 3- primary spermatocyte, 4- secondary spermatocyte, 5- early spermatid, 6- late spermatid, 7- Sertoli cell, 8- tight junction (blood-testis barrier).

questions.text:
If you furnish false information, you would be liable to punishment under:

IPC- Indian Penal Code, BNS- Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita
questions.solution:
Furnishing false information is punishable under BNS Sec 212 (177 IPC).

Other options:

BNS Sec 208 (174 IPC): deals with non-attendance in obedience to an order from a public servant.

BNS Sec 210 (175 IPC): deals with the omission to produce document(s) to a public servant by a person legally bound to produce it.

BNS Sec 211 (176 IPC): deals with the omission to give notice or information to a public servant by a person legally bound to give it.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man feels embarrassed to talk with his peers because of the persistence of a high-pitched childhood voice. At times, he has noticed that on pressing the thyroid prominence, he was able to produce an adult-type voice. Which of the following thyroplasty procedure would benefit this patient?

choices.text: Shortening or relaxation of vocal cord
Lengthening or tightening of vocal cord

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of puberphonia, also known as mutational falsetto voice. A type III thyroplasty causing shortening or relaxation of the vocal cord would benefit this patient.

When larynx matures at puberty, the voice becomes low-pitched in males. Puberphonia (mutational falsetto voice) is a condition in which the transition from high-pitched childhood voice to adult male voice fails to occur. The vocal cords are stretched and pose high tension.

Pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and a low tone voice can be produced. This is called Gutzmann’s pressure test.

In type III thyroplasty, the vocal cord is shortened and hence the tension is reduced. This can revert from a childhood voice to an adult one.

Type of thyroplasty Procedure done
Type I Medial displacement of vocal cord
Type II Lateral displacement of vocal cord
Type III Shortening (relaxation) of vocal cord
Type IV Lengthening (tightening) of vocal cord

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought by her mother with a port-wine stain on her face. CT scan showed characteristic tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. Which of the following is not an ocular finding commonly associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome. Optic nerve glioma is not an ocular finding associated with the Sturge-Weber syndrome, it is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. 

The characteristic features of Sturge-Weber syndrome include port-wine stains on the face, a history of seizures, and tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. The ocular findings commonly associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Important ocular manifestations in neurofibromatosis type 1 include:

  • Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma- S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture.
  • Optic nerve glioma - A pilocytic astrocytoma that typically occurs in young children.
  • Bilateral Lisch nodules are hamartomas that develop during the second–third decades.
  • Spheno-orbital encephalocele - due to dysplasia of the greater wing of the sphenoid

The various neurocutaneous syndromes and their ocular manifestations are as follows:

questions.text: Mitral leaflet calcification and fish mouth appearance of the mitral orifice are noted in the autopsy of a young woman. Also, small, warty vegetations on mitral valve leaflets and an enlarged left atrium are noted. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with mitral leaflet calcification, fish mouth appearance of the mitral orifice(luminal narrowing), small, warty vegetations on mitral valve leaflets and an enlarged left atrium are pathognomic of the rheumatic fever (RF) phase of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). 

RF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease classically occurring a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. RHD is principally characterized by deforming fibrotic valvular disease, particularly the mitral valve.

Important pathological findings in rheumatic fever are:

  • Inflammation in the three layers of the heart can result in endocarditis, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pancarditis.
  • Inflammation of the endocardium and the left side valves can lead to fibrinoid necrosis. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae.
  • In the subendocardium, irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques can be present.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages (called Anitschkow cells). The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Mitral valve in chronic RHD shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords.This leads to the narrowing of the mitral orifice, giving it a fish mouth appearance.

Image: Histology of a rheumatic fever patient showing Aschoff bodies and Anitschkow cells.

Other options:

Option B: Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart or mural endocardium. The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly involved. The vegetation present on the valves are large, friable, bulky, destructive lesions that contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, and bacteria or other organisms.

Option C: Marantic endocarditis/Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterised by small, sterile thrombi on the leaflets of the cardiac valves. It is seen in patients with cancer or sepsis. 

Option D: Libman-Sacks endocarditis is seen in people with systemic lupus erythematosus. They have medium to small-sized vegetation appearing on both sides of the leaflets. They may occur on any site like the surface of the valve, chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of infertility in women?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, eunuchoidism is not a cause of infertility in women. It causes infertility in males. 

Infertility is the inability of a couple to conceive after one year of regular unprotected intercourse. There are both male and female factors affecting fertility. 

Males who have Leydig cell deficiency since childhood suffer from eunuchoidism. This may be due to castration of the testes. Such men are infertile. They are tall individuals with a body habitus that resembles women, like narrow shoulders, a high-pitched voice, and sparse facial hair. Other causes of male factor infertility are:

  • Disorders of spermatogenesis
  • Obstruction of efferent ducts
  • Disorders of sperm motility
  • Sexual dysfunction

Anovulation is the most common cause of infertility in women. Physiologically, anovulation occurs during the first one to two years after menarche, lactation, and around menopause. It may also occur due to strenuous exercise. Turner’s syndrome, Sheehan’s syndrome, and hyperprolactinemia also result in anovulation.

Postpartum infarction and necrosis of the pituitary gland is called Sheehan’s syndrome (option A). It occurs in women who have shock following postpartum hemorrhage. The resultant hypopituitarism leads to ovarian atrophy, anovulation, and cessation of menstrual cycles. 

Hyperprolactinemia (option C) is the increased secretion of prolactin from the anterior pituitary. It may be seen physiologically during breastfeeding or in adenomas of the pituitary. Prolactin inhibits the action of gonadotropins on the ovaries and thus leads to anovulation and infertility. 

Turner’s syndrome or ovarian dysgenesis (option D) is a sex chromosomal abnormality. They have a 44 + XO genotype. Individuals with Turner’s syndrome are female with rudimentary ovaries. They have short stature and do not develop secondary sexual characteristics. 

The absence of ovulation can be tested by analyzing urine for a surge in pregnanediol during the luteal phase. An absence of this surge indicates anovulation. 

Other causes of female infertility include endometriosis, salpingitis, hypothyroidism, and abnormal mucus secretion by the cervix.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male baby presents with a history of fever, irritability, and vomiting. On examination, there is moderate hepatomegaly and a boiled cabbage odor. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of serum transaminases and elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine. Which enzyme is deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and laboratory findings are diagnostic of tyrosinemia type I and the enzyme deficient is fumarylacetoacetate hydroxylase (FAH).

Tyrosinemia type I or Hepatorenal tyrosinemia is caused by FAH deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive disease, caused by a defective FAH gene. This results in the accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone which are metabolites of tyrosine degradation. The tissues most affected are hepatic, renal, and nervous tissues. The manifestations of these can be seen in the form of an acute hepatic crisis, such as in this case. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin D-resistant rickets.

The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of elevated levels of succinylacetone in urine or blood. Boiled cabbage odor may be present in classical type 1 tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC) which reduces the formation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone by inhibiting the degradation of tyrosine. However, this increases the plasma levels of tyrosine. A diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine is also prescribed to patients.

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia): Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase deficiency
  • Type 2 (Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/ Richner-Hanhart syndrome): Tyrosine transaminase deficiency
  • Type 3 (Neonatal tyrosinemia)

Other options:

Option B: Tyrosine aminotransferase is deficient in tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome or oculocutaneous tyrosinemia). It is also an autosomal recessive disease that results in hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability. The laboratory finding here is marked hypertyrosinemia and elevated 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid. The treatment here also involves a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

Option C: 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase deficiency causes type III tyrosinemia (neonatal tyrosinemia). Patients might rarely have a mental disability. The liver function is generally normal. Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to deficiency of 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase.

Option D: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes phenylketonuria. It manifests as progressive intellectual disability. The diagnosis is made by measurement of plasma phenylalanine levels or by detecting phenyl ketones in the urine. A diet low in phenylalanine is the mainstay of treatment. 

The steps and enzymes of tyrosine metabolism are shown below.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented to the OPD with intractable diarrhea. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. What is the peculiar feature of this parasite which differentiates it from other coccidian parasites?

choices.text: It has Faeco-oral route of transmission
Parasites multiply asexually within the intestinal cells
Oocysts passed in the feaces are immediately infectious

questions.solution:
Oocysts passed in the feaces are immediately infectious in the case of cryptosporidium parvum, as they are sporulated oocysts.

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts suggest modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are round, containing four sporozoites which are uniformly acid-fast on staining.

In other coccidian parasites namely, cyclospora and isospora, unsporulated oocysts are passed in the stool. Unsporulated oocysts take days or weeks to become infectious, and because of this, direct person-to-person transmission through fecal exposure is unlikely to occur.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round contains 2 sporocysts each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval contains two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection Uniformly acid-fast Variably acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

Treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

 

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis.

Kinyoun stain positive images of Isospora:
