questions.text: In the graph below, which ions do A and B represent in terms of their permeability during action potential generation?

choices.text: A is Na+,  B is K+
A is Na+,  B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.solution:
In the given graph, showing action potential generation in terms of ion permeability, wave A represents Na+ and B represents K+. 

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in 7 steps as described below.

1. Resting-state - Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with facial asymmetry. On examination, there is loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, absent acoustic reflex, and normal Schirmer test. What is the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The site of lesion in this patient with loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue and absent acoustic reflex is at the tympanic segment.

Injury to the greater superficial petrosal nerve leads to loss of lacrimation which is detected by the Schirmer test. It is the first branch given at the level of the geniculate ganglion.

Injury to the nerve to stapedius, the first motor branch of the facial nerve, leads to loss of stapedial reflex and hyperacusis, which can be detected by tympanometry.

Injury to chorda tympani nerve leads to loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue which is detected by electrogustometry and reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow detected by salivary flow test.

So in this patient, the lesion is proximal to the origin of nerve to stapedius i.e. tympanic segment, and not proximal to geniculate ganglion as the lacrimation is normal.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female, with a history of chronic uncontrolled hypertension, comes to the emergency room with confusion. Patient is not oriented to place, person and time. BP is 200/120, Sr. Urea 74; Sr. Creatinine - 4.5. Which of the following drug can be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Fenoldopam is indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies. Blood pressure over 180/120 with end-organ damage is defined as hypertensive emergency.

It is a D1 agonist at peripheral D1 receptors and is a rapid-acting vasodilator.

Drugs used in a hypertensive emergency:

  • Nitroprusside
  • Nicardipine
  • Labetalol
  • Hydralazine
  • Esmolol
  • Nitroglycerine
  • Phentolamine
  • Fenoldopam

questions.text: A runner visits the emergency room after sustaining an ankle injury during a morning jog. Examination reveals tenderness over the lateral malleolus and an inability to evert the ankle joint. The X-ray performed is as shown below. Which of the following nerves carries pain sensation from this area?
questions.solution:
The X-ray of this patient shows the presence of a distal fibular fracture (lateral malleolar) not extending to the underlying joint. The superficial peroneal nerve is responsible for carrying pain sensation.

Damage to the superficial peroneal nerve would result in loss of eversion at the sub-talar joint.

The lateral compartment of the leg is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve. It consists of peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.

The anterior compartment of the leg is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve.

Contents: 

  • Tibialis anterior
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Peroneus tertius 

The posterior compartment of the leg is supplied by the tibial nerve. 

Contents:

  • Gastrocnemius
  • Soleus
  • Plantaris
  • Popliteus
  • Flexor hallucis longus
  • Flexor digitorum longus
  • Tibialis posterior

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presents with the following fingings. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings are suggestive of Bell's palsy which is a paralysis of the facial nerve. 

Facial nerve paralysis can be central or peripheral. Peripheral is more common and is usually idiopathic.

Bell's palsy is an acute onset idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis. It is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face.

It presents with an inability to close the eye, and if the patient attempts to close the eye, it turns up and out. This is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Other features include drooling of saliva and facial asymmetry. There may be noise intolerance and a loss of taste sensation.

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. Tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep and artificial tears can be used to prevent corneal drying. Most patients recover within a few weeks or months.

Other options:

Option B: Lesions of the trigeminal nerve produce numbness and paresthesias, and loss of sensation in the area supplied by the trigeminal nerve. 

Option C: In oculomotor nerve palsy, there is ptosis, a dilated pupil, and the eye appears to be down and out due to the unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique.

Option D: Glossopharyngeal nerve lesions produce difficulty swallowing, and impairment of taste over the posterior one-third of the tongue and palate. There is also impaired sensation over the posterior one-third of the tongue, palate, and pharynx, and an absent gag reflex.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of rhinitis. He is a gold smith and works in hot, dry and dusty surroundings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Rhinitis sicca is seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings.
Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers and iron- and goldsmiths. It usually affects the anterior third of the nose, particularly the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia, along with atrophy of the seromucinous glands. The affected areas develop crusts, which may result in bleeding, ulceration, and even septal perforation on removal.

Treatment consists of correction of the occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment to the affected part. Ointments with antibiotics and steroids can also be used.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinitis caseosa is a condition in which the nose is filled with purulent discharge/cheesy material. It is a unilateral condition mostly affecting males. This condition usually results from chronic sinusitis, where the mucosa of the sinuses becomes granulomatous and the sinuses are filled with cheesy material. Management includes the removal of debris and ensuring good drainage of the sinuses.

Option C: Secondary atrophic rhinitis is a condition when atrophic changes in the nasal cavity occur secondary to specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma.

Option D: Hypertrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum, and bone. It occurs as a result of recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis, and chronic irritation of the nasal mucosa. Symptoms include nasal obstruction, discharge, and headache.

questions.text: A patient was declared dead due to phosphorous poisoning. What will be the likely colour of postmortem lividity in this case?
questions.solution:
The likely color of postmortem lividity in phosphorus poisoning will be dark brown or yellow.

Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms: white phosphorus, which is highly toxic, and red phosphorus, which is non-toxic. Phosphorus is utilized in fertilizers, vermin-killers, rodenticides, fireworks, and gunpowder.

The initial stage of acute poisoning through ingestion involves severe abdominal discomfort, vomiting, and diarrhea. Excreta and breath have a garlicky odor. Luminescent feces and vomit are characteristically seen. Direct contact with the skin can result in second and third-degree burns. Shock, hematemesis due to liver failure, and renal insufficiency are potential causes of death. 

Regular inhalation of phosphorus fumes, leading to chronic phosphorus poisoning, results in necrosis of the lower jaw around a decayed tooth. This condition is known as phossy jaw and is associated with the discharge of foul-smelling pus from multiple sinuses.

Other options:

Option A: Black postmortem lividity is seen in cases of opioid poisoning.

Option B: Bluish-green postmortem lividity is seen in cases of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) poisoning.

Option C: Brick-red postmortem lividity is seen in cases of cyanide or hydrocyanic acid (HCN) poisoning.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

Poisoning/Condition Postmortem staining

Carbon monoxide   

Cherry red
Cyanides     

Brick red/dark pink

Potassium chlorate

 Chocolate brown 
Phosphorous  Dark brown 
Nitrites   

Red brown

Hydrogen sulphide

Bluish green
Opium   Grayish/black
Asphyxia Dark purple
Hypothermia Bright pink
Septic abortion (Cl. Welchii infection) Brown/pale bronze

questions.text: What structure divides the femoral nerve into its anterior and posterior divisions?
questions.solution:
The femoral nerve is split into the anterior and posterior divisions by the lateral circumflex femoral artery.

Course of Femoral Nerve:

  • Femoral nerve arises from posterior division of ventral rami of L2-L4 spinal segments on the posterior abdominal wall.
  • It enters the femoral triangle by passing under the inguinal ligament.
  • In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery and outside the femoral sheath.
  • It is divided into anterior and posterior branches by lateral circumflex femoral artery.

Note: Obturator nerve is divided into anterior and posterior divisions by obturator externus in the upper part and adductor brevis in the lower part.

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase the secretion of gastric acid?
questions.solution:
All of the given options  increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.

Serotonin is localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract. Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

The main factors that stimulate gastric secretion are acetylcholine, gastrin, and histamine. Parasympathetic stimulation releases Ach which stimulates the secretion of

  • pepsinogen by peptic cells
  • hydrochloric acid by parietal cells
  • mucus by mucous cells.

Both gastrin and histamine strongly stimulate acid secretion by parietal cells but have little effect on other cells.

The stomach mucosa has two important types of tubular glands:

  • The oxyntic (gastric) glands secrete hydrochloric acid, pepsinogen, intrinsic factor, and mucus.
  • The pyloric glands secrete mainly mucus for protection of the pyloric mucosa from the stomach acid. They also secrete the hormone gastrin.

Note- Serotonin released from the small intestine triggers vomiting by stimulation of 5HT3 receptors. Therefore, 5HT3 antagonists like ondansetron are used as antiemetics.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with vitamin K deficiency. He says he doesn't consume any leafy vegetables. Which is the compound that acts as the source of vitamin K in these vegetables?
questions.solution:
The normal dietary source of vitamin K is phylloquinone or vitamin K1, found in green leafy vegetables.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin and its deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

Three compounds have the biological activity of vitamin K:

  • Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) is the normal dietary source of Vitamin K that is found in green leafy vegetables.
  • Menaquinone (Vitamin K2) is synthesized by intestinal bacteria.
  • Menadione (Vitamin K3) and menadiol diacetate are synthetic compounds that are metabolized to phylloquinone.

questions.text: An elderly male after his retirement party came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. The fundoscopic examination picture shows a Hollenhorst plaque as in the image given below.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of sudden painless loss of vision with the presence of a Hollenhorst plaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). 

Retinal artery occlusion can occur due to emboli from the carotids, atherosclerosis-related thrombosis, retinal arteritis, raised intraocular pressure, etc. Emboli are the most common cause. They may be:

  • Cholestrol emboli or Hollenhorst plaque- at retinal vessel bifurcation, from carotid artery atheromas
  • Calcium emboli from cardiac valves
  • Platelet fibrin emboli from carotid atheromas

Patients present with sudden painless loss of vision and may have a past history of transient visual loss (amaurosis fugax). On examination, visual acuity is diminished, the direct pupillary reflex is lost and relative afferent pupillary defect is positive. On funduscopy, the following findings are seen:

  • Narrowed retinal arteries and veins
  • Milky white appearance of the retina due to edema (Option A)
  • Cherry red spot at the center of the macula (Option D)
  • Cattle trucking or segmentation of the blood column in the retinal veins (Option C)

CRAO is treated with immediate lowering of intraocular pressure, intermittent ocular massage, iv mannitol, and iv acetazolamide. Vasodilators like nitroglycerine and oral isosorbide dinitrate are helpful. Steroids for arteritis, fibrinolytic therapy, and laser photodisruption of the embolus may be done.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the action of this plant whose extracts can be used as insecticides?
questions.solution:
The given plant is pyrethrum (Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium). The extract from the flowers contains pyrethrin (nerve poison) which is used as an excellent space spray against adult mosquitos. 

Space sprays are those where the insecticidal formulation is sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog to kill insects.

Pyrethrum sprays are effective in reducing the number of mosquitoes but the reduction is only temporary since it has no residual action like DDT or other synthetic insecticides. So, most space sprays contain pyrethrum and DDT for synergistic action.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with complaints of diplopia, and progressive headache. Examination of extraocular movements revealed the findings as shown in the image, when the patient attempted to look right. Which cranial nerve lesion is likely responsible for this clinical manifestation, and which eye is affected?

choices.text: Lesion involving left abducens nerve, affecting the left eye
Lesion involving left oculomotor nerve, affecting the left eye
Lesion involving right abducens nerve, affecting the right eye
Lesion involving right oculomotor nerve, affecting the right eye

questions.solution:
The clinical finding shown in the image is suggestive of lateral rectus palsy of the right eye, which occurs due to the lesion involving right abducens nerve. 

The Abducens nerve arises from the brainstem between the pons and medulla oblongata. It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure and innervates the lateral rectus muscle through its medial (ocular surface).

Determining the palsy:

The abduction and adduction of the eye are caused by the action of the lateral rectus and medial rectus muscles respectively.

The lateral rectus is innervated by the abducens nerve (VI) while the medial rectus is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (III).

Horizontal conjugate movements occur when both eyes move horizontally to look right or left.

  • In the right gaze: The right eye abducts and the left eye adducts.
  • In the left gaze: The right eye adducts and the left eye abducts.

In the image, when the patient attempted to look right, the left eye was adducted normally, while the right eye failed to abduct. This is suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy due to the lesion involving the right abducens nerve.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is looking straight (neutral gaze), then the affected eye is the left eye. In such case, due to left lateral rectus palsy, the action of left medial rectus is unopposed causing adduction of the left eye.

questions.text: All of the following ocular findings are associated with Dorsal-Midbrain (Parinaud's) syndrome, except

choices.text: Paresis of downward gaze with preserved upward gaze

questions.solution:
Parinaud's syndrome refers to supranuclear vertical gaze disorder. Here there is a loss of up-gaze and the downward gaze is usually preserved.

Parinaud's syndrome/dorsal midbrain syndrome is caused by damage to the posterior commissure. Classically, signs of hydrocephalus are seen due to aqueductal stenosis.

Causes:

  • Pineal region or midbrain tumors (most common cause)
  • Neurocysticercosis
  • Stroke
  • Multiple sclerosis

Features include the following:

  • Loss of up-gaze (downward gaze is usually preserved)
  • Convergence–retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze
  • Downward ocular deviation- Setting-sun sign
  • Lid retraction- Collier's sign
  • Pseudo-Argyll–Robertson pupil- Accommodative paresis ensues and pupils become mid-dilated and show light-near dissociation
  • Bilateral papilledema
  • Skew deviation
  • Pseudoabducens palsy

questions.text: In an urban PHC, an increasing number of skin diseases are being reported due to inadequate water supply in the region. What would be the adequate supply of water for them to meet their needs for all domestic purposes?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of skin diseases is suggestive of water-washed diseases caused by improper hygiene related to an inadequate water supply. In urban areas, 150–200 litres per capita per day is the recommended allowance to meet the needs for all kinds of domestic purposes.
In rural areas, the set target of water supply to be achieved in India is around 40 litres per capita per day.

questions.text: A known smoker presenting with a cough was evaluated, and blood tests showed leukocytosis with no elevation in tumor markers. A chest x-ray revealed a mass in the right lung, and a biopsy of the mass showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, with the absence of tumour markers, leukocytosis, and the histopathological image showing large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate cytoplasm point to the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumour. Typical cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer are absent. This type of lung cancer does not express any of the tumour markers associated with adenocarcinoma (TTF-1, napsin A) or squamous cell carcinoma (p40, p63). On microscopy, the features described above are observed.

Tumor-related leukocytosis is commonly seen as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with large cell carcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option B - Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour. Histopathological examination shows various patterns, including acinar, papillary, lepidic, micropapillary, and solid. A histopathological image of adenocarcinoma of the lung showing glandular differentiation is given below:

Option C - Small cell carcinomas are highly malignant tumours with a strong association with cigarette smoking. Histopathological examination shows relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin in a salt-and-pepper pattern, and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The Azzopardi effect is the basophilic staining of vessel walls due to DNA residue deposited from necrotic tumour cells, as seen below:

Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant tumour associated with smoking. Histopathological examination is characterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization is seen as squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is a high mitotic activity in poorly differentiated tumours.

The image given below shows squamous pearls seen in squamous cell carcinomas.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text:
Match the following phases of the demographic cycle with their correct description.
1. High stationary a. Birth rate is less than death rate
2. Early expanding b. Both birth rate and death rate are at a low level
3. Low stationary c. High birth rate and high death rate
4. Declining stage d. Death rate starts falling but birth rate remains high
  e. Further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

1. High stationary c. High birth rate and high death rate
2. Early expanding d. Death rate starts falling but birth rate remains high
3. Low stationary b. Both birth rate and death rate are at a low level
4. Declining stage a. Birth rate is less than death rate

questions.text:
The basis of which of the following processes is depicted in the image below?

DNA- Deoxyribonucleic acid

RNA- Ribonucleic acid

mRNA- messenger RNA
questions.solution:
The process in the given image is RNA editing. 

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification.  

As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA at a single specific site. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by post-transcriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil.

DNA rearrangement, transposition, and alternate splicing also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient on salbutamol was assessed. Which of the following is not an adverse effect of the drug?
questions.solution:
Hypoglycemia is not an adverse effect of salbutamol. It causes hyperglycemia.

The side effects of salbutamol are due to the stimulation of extrapulmonary β2 receptors. They are more common after oral or intravenous administration. The side effects seen are:    

  • Muscle tremor
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypokalemia 
  • Restlessness        
  • Hypoxemia         
  • Increase in free fatty acid, insulin, glucose, pyruvate, and lactate

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient comes for routine follow-up. What is the most common ophthalmologic manifestation of HIV?
questions.solution:
Microangiopathy is the most common ocular feature of HIV infection.

It consists of the following:

  • Hemorrhages
  • Micro-aneurysm
  • Cotton-wool spots/Soft exudates (axonal debris): Most common finding of HIV retinopathy

The most common ocular adverse effect in patients receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is immune recovery uveitis (IRU). It is non-granulomatous uveitis (usually anterior uveitis and vitreitis) associated with a paradoxical or exaggerated reactivation of the immune system and an increase in intraocular inflammation following HAART for CMV chorioretinitis.

Visual complications of IRU include cataract, cystoid macular edema (CME), glaucoma, and epiretinal membrane formation.

Opportunistic infections of the eye in HIV:

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Most common cause of posterior uveitis in HIV
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Pneumocystis carinii
  • Herpes zoster

questions.text: A female patient came with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching and a sample from the discharge was cultured on CHROM agar. The colonies appear as shown in the image below. Identify the causative agent.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. The green colonies seen on CHROM agar are suggestive of Candida albicans.

CHROM agar can be used for the identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium. After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen.  Candida albicans colonies appear green, as seen above.  

Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple and Candida tropicalis colonies appear navy blue (Shown in the image below).

Candida parapsilosis, Candida lusitaniae, Candida guilliermondii, and Candida krusei colonies have a pinkish hue (Shown in the image below).

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Clinically, infection with candida can present as cutaneous & mucosal candidiasis, systemic candidiasis, or rarely, as chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Cutaneous and mucosal infections manifest as thrush affecting the tongue, lips, gums, and palate. It is seen as a patchy to confluent whitish pseudomembranous lesion and is commonly associated with AIDS. 

Candida may also invade the vaginal mucosa leading to vulvovaginitis, and the nails, and around the nail plate leading to onychomycosis.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

The clinical symptoms of vaginal candidiasis include curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching with vaginal pH <4.5. The diagnosis can be confirmed by microscopic examination of a smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution. The smear shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae (Shown in the image below).

Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells). It appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Candida albicans form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

When colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C. The image below shows germ tube formation, also known as the Reynolds Braude phenomenon, seen in Candida albicans.

questions.text: The hormone secreted by the stomach that controls food intake is _____
questions.solution:
The hormone secreted by the stomach that controls food intake is Ghrelin.

Ghrelin, the hunger hormone is produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic glands of the stomach. It increases food intake. Its levels increase during fasting, peaks just before the beginning of food intake or when the person is expecting a meal. The levels fall within 1 hour of the start of feeding.

Other options:

Option a - Orexin is synthesized from lateral hypothalamic neurons. It increases food intake.

Option b - Leptin is produced by adipocytes. It decreases food intake.

Option c - CCK is released from the small intestine. It decreases food intake.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the structure shown in the given image not seen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows psammoma bodies. They are found in all of the above mentioned conditions except in schwannoma.

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include-

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma
  • Meningiomas.

Verocay bodies are found in schwannomas. Verocay bodies are spindle cells that are arranged to form central “nuclear-free zones” ramified by palisading nuclei. Antoni A area is a dense eosinophilic area containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern. The resulting structures with central nuclear-free zones ratified by the palisading of nuclei are termed Verocay bodies.  The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

questions.text: The ECG of a patient with core body temperature of 85 °F is shown below. What is the hallmark of this patient's ECG, marked by arrows in the image below?
questions.solution:
The hallmark of this patient's ECG is the Osborn J wave.

Hypothermia is defined as core body temperature being less than 95°F and is associated with ECG changes such as: 

  • In the initial stages of hypothermia, as a reaction to the general stress, there is sinus tachycardia.
  • As the temperature drops below 90°F there is sinus bradycardia associated with prolongation of the PR interval, QRS complex, and QT interval progressively.
  • With temperature approaching 86°F, atrial ectopic activity is often noted and can progress to atrial fibrillation. It is at this level of hypothermia that many patients have Osborn waves that consist of an extra deflection at the end of the QRS complex. J waves occur when a heterogeneous distribution of potassium current enhances the activity of a transient outward potassium current in the heart, caused by low temperatures.

Osborn waves, also known as J waves, camel-hump waves or hypothermic waves, are best seen the inferior and lateral precordial leads. They become more prominent as the body temperature drops, and they regress gradually with rewarming.

A progressive widening of the QRS complex occurs when the temperature falls below 86°F, which is associated with an increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and asystole occurs when the temperature drops to ≈60°F

Other options:

Option A: Prominent U waves are seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Tall peaked T waves are the first change in the ECG as the plasma potassium level rises.

Option C: ST segment elevation is seen in Myocardial infarction.

questions.text: What structure forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle?
questions.solution:
The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the medial margin of the sartorius. Its medial boundary is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A patient was prescribed an antipsychotic drug following which he developed parkinsonism. Which of the following drugs​ can be given?
questions.solution:
Trihexyphenidyl is the drug of choice for drug-induced parkinsonism. It is a central anticholinergic.

Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition caused by certain drugs having D2 antagonistic action (typical antipsychotics). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring the balance.

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy, who is a known case of asthma, presents with wheezing and rhinitis. Laboratory results show peripheral eosinophilia and antibodies against neutrophil myeloperoxidase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the lab findings are suggestive of Churg–Strauss syndrome.

Churg-Strauss Syndrome/Allergic granulomatosis and angiitis is a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis classically associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

It is a multisystem disease with cutaneous involvement (palpable purpura), gastrointestinal tract bleeding, and renal disease. Eosinophilic infiltrates may also be seen in the myocardium giving rise to cardiomyopathy.

p- ANCA (MPO-ANCA) is positive in about 50% of cases. Histological features are similar to those observed in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) or microscopic polyangiitis but characteristically accompanied by granulomas and eosinophils.

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby girl with a rash as shown below and patent ductus arteriosus. All of the following are the ocular findings associated with this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing blueberry muffin lesions is suggestive of Congenital rubella syndrome and microphthalmos is seen in this condition (not megalophthalmos).

Congenital rubella cataract may occur alone or as part of the classical rubella syndrome which consists of:

  • Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with Trendelenburg sign positive on one side. Which of the following muscles are involved?

choices.text: Lateral rotators of the hip joint

questions.solution:
The muscles involved in a positive Trendelenburg sign are the hip abductors—the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus.

The gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Stabilizing the pelvis on the femur during walking is done by these muscles. It is demonstrated by asking the subject to stand on one limb. If the ipsilateral abductors are normal, the pelvis remains in a horizontal position. If the ipsilateral abductors are weak, then the pelvis tilts towards the opposite (unsupported) side. This is called positive Trendelenburg’s sign.

Other causes of positive Trendelenburg signs include shortening of the femoral neck, abductor tendon rupture, and dislocation or subluxation of the hip joint. 

Patients are known to have a characteristic gait, which is called Trendelenburg or waddling gait. The trunk is thrown from side to side with each step, and the patient lurches toward the unaffected limb while walking.

The image below depicts Trendelenburg's gait.

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A young athlete while running a marathon had a sudden cardiac arrest and died. Based on the histological findings of the patient’s heart given below, identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young athlete with sudden cardiac arrest with the histological feature of haphazard disarray of myofibrils is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a common autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy, abnormal diastolic filling (with preserved systolic function), and intermittent left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. It is the leading cause of unexplained left ventricular hypertrophy.

It is caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomeric proteins, including myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7). It can also rarely occur due to mutations in genes coding for cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin. 

In HCM, myocardial hypertrophy occurs without ventricular dilation. Furthermore, there is asymmetric septal hypertrophy, where the ventricular septum is disproportionately thickened compared to the left ventricular free wall. The enlarged septum bulges into the ventricular cavity, giving it a banana-like shape. Hypertrophy is most marked in the subaortic region of the septum.

The most important histologic features of HCM are:

  • Massive myocyte hypertrophy
  • Myofiber disarray including that of myocyte bundles, individual myocytes, and contractile elements
  • Fibrotic narrowing of small intramural arteries
  • Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

The images below show normal cardiac myocytes and myofibril disarray in HCM, respectively:

 

Exertional dyspnea due to reduced cardiac output is seen, and a harsh systolic ejection murmur caused due to LVOT obstruction can be heard. Further, atrial fibrillation, stroke due to mural thrombus formation, and ventricular arrhythmias are common complications of HCM. 

β-adrenergic blockers can be used to decrease heart rate and contractility, and implantable cardioverter defibrillators are used for patients with ventricular arrhythmias.

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) occurs due to truncating mutations in the titin gene. The heart in DCM is flabby and hypo-contracting, in contrast with the thick-walled, heavy, and hyper-contracting heart in HCM. Histology reveals hypertrophied myocytes with hyperchromatic distorted nuclei with a ninja star-like appearance, as shown in the image below. Variable degrees of interstitial and endocardial fibrosis is also present.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an autosomal dominant disorder that occurs due to mutations of genes encoding desmosomal junctional proteins. It typically manifests as right-sided heart failure and can cause sudden cardiac death. Histology shows loss of myocytes, fatty infiltration, and focal fibrosis.

Option D: In restrictive cardiomyopathy, patients will have stiffened myocardial walls with diastolic dysfunction. It is associated with cardiac amyloidosis and on histological examination, hyaline, amorphous eosinophilic deposits are seen. Transthyretin is the major component of cardiac amyloid deposits. Histological findings of cardiac amyloidosis are shown below.

Related Pearl: One-liners on Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

  • Missense mutation

questions.text:
Match the following triage tags with the appropriate traumatic conditions.
Triage tag Condition
1. Black A. Flail chest
2. Red B. Pelvic fracture
3. Green C. Extensive third-degree burns
4. Yellow D. Sprain of the ankle
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option C: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

Triage tag Patient
1. Black C. Extensive third-degree burns
2. Red A. Flail chest
3. Green D. Sprain of the ankle
4. Yellow B. Pelvic fracture

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment.

It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. It lessens the burden on medical facilities.

The internationally accepted four-color coded system is used commonly:

  • Red - First (I) priority; Immediate attention or transfer; Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Yellow - Second (II) priority; Urgent, Critical, likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Green - Third (III) Non-urgent; Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Black - Last (0) Unsalvageable; Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text:
A physiologist is investigating the effects of high altitude on monks residing in the Himalayas. Which of the following physiological parameters would NOT be expected to be increased in them?

(BPG - Bisphosphoglycerate)
(Hb- Hemoglobin)
questions.solution:
The physiological parameters that would be increased in the monks as a result of acclimatization to high altitude are 2,3- BPG levels, mitochondrial density, and Myoglobin concentration. The affinity of Hb for Oxygen will decrease.

When a person ascends to a high altitude and stays there for longer periods usually, he/she gets adapted to the new environment. This process is called acclimatization. The mechanisms behind acclimatization are an increase in pulmonary ventilation; increased numbers of RBCs; increased diffusing capacity of the lungs; increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues; and increased ability of the tissue cells to use O2, despite a low Po2.

RBCs lack mitochondria and enzymes like cytochrome oxidase, hence anaerobic glycolysis is the source of energy. At high altitudes, concentration of 2-3 BPG (an intermediate of glycolysis) increases in RBCs and it tends to decrease the O2 affinity of hemoglobin. The net effect is a small increase in P50. The decrease in O2 affinity facilitates the unloading of oxygen from RBCs thus making more O2 available to the tissues.

Other physiological changes that occur during acclimatization include

  • Increased erythropoietin secretion, leads to an increase in the number of circulating RBCs, hematocrit, hemoglobin concentration, and blood volume.
  • Increased number of mitochondria in tissues like skeletal muscles. Increased myoglobin in muscles to facilitate the movement of O2 into the tissues
  • Increased tissue cytochrome oxidase (oxidative enzymes).
  • Increased vascularity / capillary density in tissues.
  • Increased cardiac output.
  • Increased diffusing capacity of lungs for O2.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a medial pathway involved in maintenance of posture?
questions.solution:
The rubrospinal tract is a part of the lateral brainstem pathway.

  • The medial brainstem pathways : pontine and medullary reticulospinal, vestibulospinal, and tectospinal tracts.
    • These pathways descend in the ipsilateral ventral columns of the spinal cord and terminate predominantly on interneurons in the ventromedial part of the ventral horn to control axial and proximal muscles. 
  • The lateral brainstem pathways : The corticospinal tract and the rubrospinal tract.
    • They cross the midline and project to interneurons in the dorsolateral part of the spinal ventral horn to also influence motor neurons that control distal limb muscles.
    • The rubrospinal tract excites flexor motor neurons and inhibits extensor motor neurons. This pathway may play a role in the posture typical of decorticate rigidity.

questions.text: An immunocompromised individual is diagnosed to have Pneumocystis jirovecii infection. Which of the following statements is false about this organism?

choices.text: Cyst wall stains black with methenamine silver stain
It grows readily on Sabouraud agar
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used for prophylaxis in HIV patients

questions.solution:
Pneumocystis jirovecii can not be cultured in vitro and the diagnosis depends on direct visualization of cysts and/or trophozoites in lower respiratory tract specimens.

P. jirovecii has three morphological forms:

  • Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped
  • Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase
  • Cyst - thick-walled, spherical in shape. It contains intracystic bodies

Trophozoites can be demonstrated by Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains. The cyst wall stains black with methenamine silver stain.

 

Infection is transmitted by respiratory droplets. It is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, it causes life-threatening pneumonia called pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). PCP is one of the common opportunistic infections in AIDS. Patients with PCP generally present with fever and a non-productive cough with dyspnea. 

The diagnosis is made by highly specific staining of the cyst in the lung tissue or pulmonary secretions with methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa or by staining with a specific immunofluorescent antibody. The presence of organisms in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid is almost 100% sensitive and specific for PCP in patients with HIV infection. Perihilar diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates are classically seen on radiographs. Cysts and pneumothoraces are common chest radiographic findings.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) and pentamidine isothionate are the drugs of choice for the treatment of acute cases. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is also used for prophylaxis in HIV patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pathognomonic sign of anterior uveitis?
questions.solution:
The pathognomonic sign of anterior uveitis is keratic precipitates (KP).

These are proteinaceous cellular deposits occurring at the back of the cornea. The composition and morphology of KPs vary with the type of uveitis.

  • Mutton fat KPs are seen in granulomatous uveitis. These are composed of epitheloid cells and macrophages. Granulomatous uveitis may also have Koeppe nodules (on the pupillary border) and Busacca nodules (on the surface of iris).
  • Small and medium KPs (granular) are seen in non-granulomatous uveitis. They are composed of lymphocytes.
  • Fine/Stellate KPs are associated with Fuchs heterochromatic iridocyclitis, herpetic iritis, and cytomegalovirus retinitis.
  • Old KPs are an indication of healed uveitis.

questions.text: According to IMNCI, pneumonia is classified by _______
questions.solution:
Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with cough or difficult breathing:

  • Respiratory rate
    • which distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not
    • > 50 for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40 for children 12 months to 5 years of age
  • Lower chest wall indrawing
    • which indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor
    • which indicates those with severe pneumonia who require hospital admission.

The following table gives the classification for cough / difficult breathing from 2 months to 5 years of age:

The recent WHO guidelines states that chest indrawing and fast breathing is in category of pneumonia. 

Signs of severe pneumonia is not able to drink, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargic or unconscious, stridor in a calm child or severe malnutrition.

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair among the following.
questions.solution:
Clostridium perfringens - subterminal spores are the correct pair. 

The shape and position of spores vary in different species and these are used in the identification and classification of Clostridium as follows:

  1. Central or equatorial:  Clostridium bifermentans
  2. Subterminal: Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium novyi, and Clostridium botulinum
  3. Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped): Clostridium tertium and Clostridium difficle
  4. Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): Clostridium tetani

The genus Clostridium consists of gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacilli. The spores are wider than the bacillary bodies, giving the bacillus a swollen appearance, resembling a spindle. Hence, the name Clostridium.

The image given below shows subterminal spores that can be seen in Clostridium perfringens and Clostridium botulinum which cause gas gangrene and botulism respectively.

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatric department with characteristic hair as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzyme actions will not be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the image showing an irritable child with kinky colorless, and sparse hair with truncal hypotonia on examination is suggestive of Menke's disease and in this condition, copper is deficient since it is not mobilized from the intestine. Glutathione peroxidase action is not affected since it requires selenium in the form of selenocysteine and not copper.

Copper is a part of numerous enzymes like:

  • Amine oxidases
  • Ferroxidase (ceruloplasmin)
  • Cytochrome c oxidase
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Tyrosinase (melanin synthesis)
  • Lysyl oxidase (cross-linking in collagen)
  • Dopamine hydroxylase.

It is also a component of ferroportin, which is involved in iron absorption.

Copper deficiency disorders:

Wilson’s disease: It is an autosomal recessive disorder, due to ATP7 B mutation, a gene encoding for copper transporting ATPase in the cells. There is defective biliary copper excretion from liver cells, leading to copper deposits in the liver and brain.

Menke’s (Kinky or Steely) hair syndrome: It is an X-linked recessive condition, where there is a mutation in the ATP7A gene. There is defective copper-binding P-type ATPase and copper is not mobilized from the intestine.

MEDNIK syndrome: A rare multisystem disorder of copper metabolism with features of both Wilson’s and Menke’s disease.

questions.text: The given area of the anterior surface of the left kidney is related to the ________________ :
questions.solution:
The given area on the anterior surface of the left kidney is related to the jejunum.

 The anterior relations of the right kidney include:

  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Second/descending part of the duodenum
  • Liver
  • Hepatic flexure of the colon
  • Small intestine

The anterior relations of the left kidney include:

  • Left suprarenal gland 
  • Stomach
  • Pancreas
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
  • Splenic flexure and the beginning of the descending colon

The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows:

  • Vessels (1): Subcostal vessels
  • Ligaments (2): Medial and Lateral Arcuate ligaments
  • Nerves (3): Subcostal, Iliohypogastric, and Ilioinguinal nerves
  • Muscles (4): Diaphragm, Psoas major, Quadratus lumborum, and Transverses abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent  Fundus Fluorescent  Angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below, which is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The FFA image shows features suggestive of macular ischemia. The FFA is showing an enlarged fovea avascular zone arrow(white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow) - both of which are suggestive of macular ischemia which when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points towards diabetic macular ischemia

Interpreting Fluorescein angiography image:

  • Punctate (pinpoint) areas of hyper fluorescence - Microaneurysms
  • Abnormal branching or dilatation of blood vessels - intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) or retinal neovascularization
  • Fluorescein leakage - Retinal neovascularization. Leakage in the disc region suggests neovascularization of the disc and leakage in other regions proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  • Patchy non-perfused retinal capillaries (seen as filling defects in capillaries) - Ischemia from nonperfused retinal capillaries
  • Increase in the size of the foveal avascular zone - Macular ischemia 

Other Options:

  • Macular oedema would show the characteristic Petaloid appearance
  • Submacular/subretinal haemorrhage would obscure the choroidal dye visualization in the corresponding area, appearing similar to capillary nonperfusion but spreading across vascular zones without a defined pattern. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however, be visualized.
  • Premacular haemorrhage/ Vitreous haemorrhage would obscure the visualization of retinal vasculature even and would appear as a region of hypofluorescence with no retinal vasculature visualization

questions.text: An infant demonstrates lethargy, vomiting, and convulsions after a few sessions of breastfeeding. The patient was diagnosed with hyperammonemia type-1. Which of the following statement is the enzyme deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The enzyme defective in hyperammonemia type-1 is carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I). 

CPS I catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle and is present in the mitochondria. This reaction uses NH3 and CO2 as substrates to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate. It is a mitochondrial enzyme. Its defect leads to hyperammonemia type 1.

The clinical symptoms of urea cycle disorders include vomiting, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, severe mental retardation, hypothermia, and apnea due to high plasma ammonia levels.

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is the rate-limiting enzyme in pyrimidine synthesis. It is inhibited by UTP (uridine triphosphate) and activated by ATP and PRPP (phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate).

CPS I  CPS II
Rate-limiting enzyme of urea cycle Rate limiting step of pyrimidine synthesis
Found in mitochondria Found in cytosol
Uses ammonia as a source of nitrogen Uses glutamine as a source of nitrogen
Requires N-acetyl glutamate as a positive allosteric activator Does not require N-acetyl glutamate

Option C: Ornithine transcarbamoylase combines carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. Deficiency causes elevated glutamine levels in the blood, CSF, and urine.

Option D: Argininosuccinate synthetase leads to the synthesis of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate.

questions.text: Which of the following is a modified long bone?
questions.solution:
The clavicle is a modified long bone, as it has a modified shaft and no medullary cavity.

Long bones are classified as follows:

  • Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends (epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end. E.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula.  
  • Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. E.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.
  • Modified long bones have a modified shaft or ends, and no medullary cavity. E.g., clavicle.

questions.text: A patient with lymphatic filarisis is being managed as shown in the image below. What is the level of prevention done here?
questions.solution:
The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection. Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

Other options:

Option A: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

Option C: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

Option D: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation

Specific causal or risk factors

Early stage of disease

Late stage of disease

Aim

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Early detection and intervention to minimize disability

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Modes of Intervention

Health education

Health promotion and specific protection

 

Diagnosis and treatment

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

Targets

Total population or select groups

Total population or high risk individuals/groups

 

Individuals/ Patients
