questions.text: Which of the following is both a diffusion and dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Epsilometer method (E-test) is both a diffusion and dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity. It is a quantitative technique for determining the antimicrobial susceptibility (AST) and MIC (in µg/mL) of gram-negative and gram-positive aerobic bacteria.

The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows:

  • Diffusion methods: Kirby–Bauer method, Stokes method
  • Dilution methods: Tube dilution, Agar dilution
  • Diffusion and dilution method: E–test (Epsilometer)

questions.text: You are a part of a critical care analysis that involves the quality improvement of patient care in the hospital. This helps in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The critical path analysis or critical plan method helps in understanding potential delays to the completion of a project. 

The critical path in the critical path method (CPM) is the longest path in the completion of a network or a project. Any delay in the events of a critical path will result in a delay in the entire project. 

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A young man presents with a painless mass in the submandibular region. On performing drainage, the discharge contained yellow granules and was foul-smelling. Microscopy of the sample showed gram-positive filamentous rods. Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of cervicofacial actinomycosis. The patient presents with a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. Penicillin G is the drug of choice.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria, primarily of the genus Actinomyces.

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis: Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance). Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of the Actinomyces colonies.

Treatment involves surgical drainage or excision along with high doses of intravenous penicillin G over two to six weeks, followed by oral penicillin V.

questions.text: A scientist is working on some formulae to calculate the heart rate and cardiac output. Which of the following cannot be used to calculate the cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Ventilation-perfusion scan cannot be used to measure the cardiac output. Fick principle, thermodilution, and ECHO can be used to measure cardiac output. 

Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by the heart into the aorta every minute. The average cardiac output is 5L/min and can be measured by various indirect methods.

Fick's principle uses the total amount of oxygen absorbed from the air by the lungs and the arteriovenous oxygen difference of blood to calculate the cardiac output using the following formula:

Cardiac output (L/min) = (O2 absorbed per minute by the lungs (mL/min))  /  (Arterio-venous O2 difference(mL/L of blood))                                       

Thermodilution method employs cold saline which is infused into the right atrium through a double-lumen Swan–Ganz thermodilution catheter and the temperature change is measured at the pulmonary artery using a thermistor at the end of the catheter. The mean decrease in the temperature of blood is inversely proportional to the cardiac output.

An ECHO uses ultrasound waves from a transducer placed on the chest wall to measure the velocity of blood flowing from the left ventricle into the aorta. Stroke volume can be calculated from this. Cardiac Output = Heart Rate X Stroke Volume.

The other methods that can be used to measure cardiac output include impedance cardiography a.k.a. thoracic electrical bioimpedance, electromagnetic or ultrasonic flowmeter,and  indicator dilution method.

Ventilation-perfusion scan is not a method of cardiac output measurement. It is used to assess pulmonary circulation.

questions.text: During a neurological examination of a patient with hand weakness, the physician observes impaired movement in the 1st lumbrical muscle. Which nerve primarily innervates this muscle?
questions.solution:
The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked. 

There are four lumbrical muscles. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. It passes to the radial side of the corresponding fingers and is inserted into the dorsal digital expansion of the extensor digitorum.

The action of lumbricals is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint and extension of interphalangeal joints. 

Lumbricals can be tested only along with interosseous muscle. The examiner will hold the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger in hyperextension. Then the patient is asked to extend the proximal interphalangeal joint against resistance. The test is repeated on other fingers as well.

The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals. The deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the third and the fourth. 

The median nerve is formed by the union of the lateral root (C6, 7) from the lateral cord, and the medial root (C8, T1) from the medial cord.

On the hand, it is seen proximal to the flexor retinaculum and lateral to the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis. It also lies between the tendons of flexor carpi radialis and palmaris longus.

Its cutaneous supply in hand is as follows: 

  • Lateral 2/3rd of the palm by superficial cutaneous branch
  • Lateral 3½ fingers (palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of nailbeds) by palmar digital nerves

The muscles supplied by the median nerve in the hand are flexor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and first dorsal interosseous.

The median nerve sometimes gets compressed under the fibro-osseous tunnel beneath the flexor retinaculum leading to carpal tunnel syndrome. 

Pen test is used to test the median nerve in the hand. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.  The hand must remain flat with the palm facing upwards. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used for antibiotic sensitivity testing?
questions.solution:
Lawn culture is used for antibiotic sensitivity testing.

Methods used in bacterial culture: 

  • Streak culture: It is routinely used for isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens.
  • Lawn culture/carpet culture : It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing.
  • Stroke culture: It is employed for providing pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests.
  • Stab culture: It is used for demonstration of gelatin liquefaction and oxygen requirements of bacterium, for maintainance of stock cultures. 
  • Pour plate culture: It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension.
  • Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances.

The image below shows lawn culture.

questions.text: During a radiographical imaging procedure, a person is positioned in such a way that the X-ray beam comes from a 30-degree cephalocaudal angle as shown in the image given below. The X-ray view shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The X-ray view shown in the image is Schuller’s view.

Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of the skull. The central beam of X-rays passes from one side of the head and is at an angle of 30° to the radiographic plate. The key area seen in this view is the antrum and upper part of the attic. This angulation prevents overlap of images of two mastoid bones. The radiograph for each mastoid is taken separately.

Other options:

Option A: Law’s view: the patient lies in such a way that the sagittal plane of the skull is parallel to the film and the X-ray beam is projected 15° cephalocaudal, a lateral mastoid air cells view without overlap of the opposite side. The below image shows Law’s view.

Option C: Towne’s view: angled anteroposterior view used to demonstrate the occipital bone, foramen magnum, dorsum sellae, and petrous ridges.

Option D: Caldwell's view (or occipitofrontal view) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 20° to orbitomeatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

questions.text: Laminar dot sign is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Laminar dot sign is an advanced glaucomatous change in the optic disc.

It is because the pores in the lamina cribrosa are slit-shaped and are visible up to the margin of the disc.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc

Early glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertically oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayonetting sign: Sharp angulation of vessel at margin of excavated cup
  • Laminar dot sign

 

Image: Glaucomatous optic atrophy

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a condition affecting the conducting airways of the respiratory pathway through biopsy. After starting treatment, it is observed months later that new cells have proliferated. Which of the following cells is responsible for the recovery in this patient?
questions.solution:
The cells responsible for recovery and new cell proliferation following damage to the conducting airways are Clara cells.

Club cells, also known as Clara cells, are specialized secretory cells found in the bronchioles that do not possess cilia. They act as progenitor cells and help in bronchial regeneration after injury. They also secrete essential defense markers and contribute to the composition of mucus through the secretion of a nonmucinous material containing carbohydrates and proteins.

Other options:

Option A: Type II pneumocytes are stem cells that are found in the alveoli ( respiratory zone) and not in the conducting zone. They help in replenishing damaged Type I pneumocytes. These cells possess superoxide dismutase, making them more resistant to toxic oxygen radicals. As a result, they can survive, proliferate, and differentiate into Type I cells to restore the normal alveolar architecture

Option C: Neuroendocrine cells or Kulchitsky cells form part of the neuroendocrine system of Amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) cells. These cells manufacture amines and store and secrete biologically active peptides like Substance P and Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). They are not involved in tissue regeneration.

Option D: Pulmonary alveolar macrophages (PAM) or dust cells originate from the bone marrow and possess active phagocytic abilities. They play a role in engulfing small particles that manage to bypass the mucociliary escalator and reach the alveoli. They do not possess stem cell function.

questions.text: An epidemiologist plans to conduct a prospective study instead of a retrospective study. Which of the following disadvantages does he aim to eliminate by conducting this study?
questions.solution:
Recall bias can be eliminated in a prospective study.

Memory or recall bias: When cases and controls are asked questions about their past history, it may be more likely for the cases to recall the existence of certain events or factors, than the controls who are healthy persons. For example, those who have had a myocardial infarction might be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events than those who have not. Thus cases may have a different recall of past events than controls.

Prospective studies begin in the present and continue into future. Hence there will be minimal change for recall bias.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: What condition is depicted by the subcutaneous venous circulation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the upward flow of subcutaneous venous circulation can be seen in inferior vena cava obstruction.

The level of the umbilicus is a watershed area for venous and lymphatic circulation. The systemic veins anastomose with tributaries of portal veins at the umbilicus. Normally, venous blood and lymphatics flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus and downwards below this plane. 

  • In inferior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal wall is completely upward.
  • In superior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal veins is completely downward.
  • In portal hypertension with dilated abdominal veins, the blood flow is away from the umbilicus, radiating like a star from the umbilicus (caput-medusae).

Causes of superior and inferior vena caval obstruction:

Causes of SVC obstruction Causes of IVC obstruction 

 

1. Mediastinal malignancy

2. Mediastinal fibrosis

3. Retrosternal thyroid

4. Aortic aneurysm

5. Radiation fibrosis

6. Iatrogenic
  1.  Thrombosis extension
  2.  Tumor invasion
  3.  Extrinsic compression (Eg: Pregnancy, abdominal mass)
  4. Coagulopathy
  5. Sepsis, dehydration, immobility
  6. Iatrogenic

Splenic vein thrombosis is one of the prehepatic causes of portal hypertension, in which the portal venous system is affected before it enters the liver.

questions.text: A child has complaints of hematuria, mild sensorineural hearing loss, and eye defects. His renal biopsy on electron microscopy showed a basket-weave appearance. What type of collagen is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hematuria, mild sensorineural hearing loss, eye defects, and the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) in electron microscopy are highly suggestive of Alport syndrome. It is a glomerular basement membrane disease that is caused due to mutations in the type IV collagen genes.

The GBM in Alport syndrome shows irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning), and pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa, often producing the basket-weave appearance.

It is hereditary and can be inherited as an X-linked, autosomal dominant, or autosomal recessive disorder. However, the most common mode of inheritance of classic Alport syndrome is X-linked. Therefore, male relatives tend to be affected as in this case. 

Clinically, the classic variant of Alport syndrome presents with hematuria due to nephritis that slowly progresses to end-stage renal disease, an anterior lenticonus, and a mild, non-progressive sensorineural hearing loss that usually involves higher frequencies. Other eye findings include lens dislocation, corneal dystrophy, and posterior cataracts.

The investigation involves biopsy and histopathologic examination which includes the following findings-

  • Light microscopy: Glomeruli appear normal until late in the disease course. End-stage renal disease can show histological features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
  • Electron microscopy: Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning), and pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa producing a distinctive basket-weave appearance.
  • Immunofluorescence: No deposits.

Image: Basket-weave appearance in Alport syndrome

Other options:

Option B: Deficiency of type I collagen synthesis causes osteogenesis imperfecta. It presents as postnatal fractures, blue sclera, lax joints, fragile skeleton, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and normal stature.

Option C: Deficiency of type III collagen is associated with vascular type IV Ehler-Danlos syndrome. It presents as thin easily bruisable skin, arterial and uterine rupture, and joint hyperextensibility.

Option D: Deficiency of type II collagen is associated with skeletal dysplasia, and ocular findings such as lens subluxation, cataract, myopia, etc, hearing impairment, and facial features.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Nephritic syndrome:

questions.text: A surgeon assessed a clean, sutured, uninfected surgical wound of a patient on day 5. According to the stages of wound healing by first intention, what event is expected to happen now?

choices.text: Migration of epithelial cells toward the center

questions.solution:
A clean, sutured, uninfected surgical wound is one of the examples of healing by the first intention. On the fifth day of the wound, the formation of new blood vessels (neovascularization) is expected to take place according to the sequence of events in wound healing.

Other options:

Option A: Replacement of neutrophils by macrophages occurs on day 3.

Option B: Proliferation of fibroblasts occurs in the second week.

Option D: Migration of epithelial cells toward the centre takes place within 24-48 hours.

The sequence of events in wound healing is as follows:

Time after injury Events
Within 24 hours

Neutrophils:

  • Migrate from the incision margin towards the fibrin clot
  • Release proteolytic enzymes that begin to clear the debris

Basal cells: 

  • Located at the cut edge of the epidermis
  • Show increased mitotic activity
24 to 48 hours

Epithelial cells:

  • Migrate and proliferate from the wound edges towards the center 
  • Deposit basement membrane components 
  • Form a continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound
Day 3
  • Macrophages become predominant, with very few neutrophils 
  • Granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space
  • Collagen fibers at the incision margins
  • Increased thickness of the epithelial layer through continued epithelial proliferation 
Day 5
  • Neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space
  • As new vessels are leaky, new granulation tissue is often edematous
2nd week
  • Continued collagen accumulation
  • Fibroblast proliferation.
End of the 1st month
  • Scar contains cellular connective tissue
  • Largely devoid of inflammatory cells
  • Covered by an essentially normal epidermis
